dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The STEADY FOOTFALL OF A WOMAN’s BOOTS, sinking in wet sand- The RISE and FALL of a WOMAN’s breath- MRS GEORGE WHARTON ROBINSON aka ‘NELLY’, head down consum by thought, etching a line across the sand, like charcoal on paper until- NELLY stops looking out at the endless grey Margate coastline beyond, eyes dark and lost in some deep trouble distraction, a sense she has walked as far as the landsca will let her- Heart beating, chest rising, she stands until- She turns, head down, once more walking, as she picks up her pace- The swoop and call of gulls, skimming the pier, overhead. INT. SCHOOL HALL. SCHOOLHOUSE. MARGATE. DAY. 1885.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A school hall- On a raised stage, a YOUNG SCHOOL BOY in fake moustache dressed as a waiter, stands in waiting. Two more SCHOOLBOYS, dressed in climbing costumes, sit at a cafe table close by. A back cloth of the Swiss Alps strung up behind. A young male teacher MR LAMBOURNE [late 20's] hovers distracted, clearly trying to organise an errant backstage. In the wings just visible, PROP MAKERS and STAGE MANAGERS adjust collars on SCHOOLBOY ACTORS; An angelic LION [6 yr waits with OTHERS, bored and tired in floormop wig and painted nose, yawning as he peeks out to the auditorium beyond to see- REVEREND WILLIAM BENHAM [mid 50’s] sits, silently waiting in the makeshift stalls, reading through a playscript entitled- No Thoroughfare: A Drama in Five Acts by Charles Dickens and Wilkie Collins. Beyond a small orchestra of SCHOOLBOYS just visible ina makeshift orchestra pit; a JOLLY SCHOOLBOY PERCUSSIONIST tightens a nut on a wide drum. A TEENAGE VIOLINIST waxes the strings on a viola, a SCHOOLBOY OBOIST and PIANIST quietly tune up, looking to the clock overhead. The SENSE OF TIME TICKING ON-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Blue Revisions dated 11th June 2012 2.

dialogues.speaker: DISTANT MURMUR OF VOICES PASSING-
dialogues.text: MR GEORGE WHARTON[early 30's] headmaster, clergyman and husband, just visible escorting a PORTLY PARENT along a distant corridor.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Here is the theatre. The boys always perform a short play at the end of term, highly popular with the parents. Theatre is an abiding interest of my wife’s. Which of course I delight in! He smiles at BENHAM, a shared look of quizzical concern, clock ticking overhead.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Is she still not here? BENHAM shrugs, smiles benignly.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Mr and Mrs Featherstone may I introduce Mr Benham. Mr Benham is invaluable to the school. He assists my wife with penny readings and other charitable events. You will often find them in corners plotting their next money raising venture. The CAST, ORCHESTRA and BENHAM wait on-

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (moving on) Shall we move on?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: NELLY clambering over sandy dune seeing a small town in t distance. She hurries on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: NELLY ascends a small path in the town. She walks briskly towards a schoolhouse and enters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MARY, the maid carrying a tray with oil lamps on passing GEORGE and the PORTLY PARENT heading towards the study-  Blue Revisions dated 11th June 2012 3.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Mary, tea if you please. MARY quietly disgruntled, slides the tray down, turning to head back to the kitchen. A shadowy figure just visible through the glass, NELLY on the approach- The SWING OF THE FRONT DOOR open, NELLY hurriedly pulling off hat and scarf, just seeing GEORGE, closing the door o his study-

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (hushed) Mr Benham has been here since-

dialogues.speaker: NELLY
dialogues.text: (nods ) Yes..Yes..I am so sorry.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Mr Lambourne has been organising the boys as best he can.

dialogues.speaker: NELLY
dialogues.text: I lost all sense of time. NELLY hurrying along the corridor, a sense of activity as she passes-—

dialogues.speaker: NELLY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (in passing) Careful with those corners, Langan- A SCHOOLBOY nods, carrying a huge piece of scenery with ANOTHER BOY follow NELLY through a distant door into- INT. SCHOOLHALL. MARGATE. DAY. 1885.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And at once, NELLY is on- The SCHOOLBOYS smile with relief on seeing-

dialogues.speaker: NELLY
dialogues.text: Mr Benham I am so sorry..I am here..I am here. NELLY looking to the SCHOOLBOYS with a reassuring smile a a smile of thanks to LAMBOURNE.

dialogues.speaker: NELLY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (to all) Forgive me. Dear Boys. NELLY, energy infectious, lights up the room as she enter  Blue Revisions dated 11th June 2012 4.

dialogues.speaker: NELLY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Let’s go from the third act. Mr Benham must not see all our tricks quite yet or there will be nothing left to show him tomorrow.

dialogues.speaker: BENHAM
dialogues.text: It is cold outside.

dialogues.speaker: NELLY
dialogues.text: It is. But it clears the mind.

dialogues.speaker: BENHAM
dialogues.text: It does. It does. BENHAM clutches a couple of volumes of DICKENS- Great Expectations and David Copperfield.

dialogues.speaker: BENHAM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: It would be good to decide on the readings before the end of term.

dialogues.speaker: NELLY
dialogues.text: Yes..Yes of course..I am happy to consider your suggestions. Maybe later? NELLY wavers, nods, smiles, turning her attention back to the boys.

dialogues.speaker: NELLY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Laurenson? Tanner? Are we ready? Good. NELLY smiles at the SCHOOLBOY ACTORS, with encouragement. She nods to MR LAMBOURNE.

dialogues.speaker: NELLY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Mr Lambourne, are you happy with everything as it is? LAMBOURNE nods.

dialogues.speaker: NELLY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (eyeing WAITER) The moustaches works well, I think. SUDDENLY GEOFFREY WHARTON ROBINSON[6yrs] the angelic lion peers from behind the wings. NELLY, eyes him

dialogues.speaker: NELLY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: No Geoffrey, dear. Not yet. You come in on the final line. (hushed) We don’t want to scare Mr Benham just yet or he may not return.  Blue Revisions dated 11th June 2012 5. GEOFFREY nods, NELLY smiles, hurrying to take her place next to BENHAM.

dialogues.speaker: BENHAM
dialogues.text: I recall no lion in Mr Dickens and Mr Collins Play, Mrs Wharton Robinson.

dialogues.speaker: NELLY
dialogues.text: A little dramatic licence. I am confident that Mr Dickens would have let it pass- NELLY deflects, with a smile.

dialogues.speaker: NELLY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Shall we begin? NELLY nods to an OLD STAGE MANAGER.

dialogues.speaker: NELLY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Yates, would you drop the backing. The OLD STAGE MANAGER nods, hurrying to drop a scenery cl revealing a mountain landscape. The SCHOOLBOYS begin a short musical introduction. MR LAMBOURNE indicates the pace with a nod of his head.

dialogues.speaker: SCHOOL BOY 1
dialogues.text: Well, my lads, the day is breaking at last. NELLY is up at once-

dialogues.speaker: NELLY
dialogues.text: ..-No..the day has broken,Hadley. On BENHAM noticing-

dialogues.speaker: NELLY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Lets get it right. The EARNEST SCHOOLBOY MOUNTAINEER nods.

dialogues.speaker: SCHOOL BOY 1
dialogues.text: Well, my lads the day has broken- NELLY consoled, offers a nod and we are away as the SCENE BREAKS into life on the stage, as the SCHOOLBOY WAITER se coffee to the SCHOOLBOY MOUNTAINEERS, lost in earnest act SCHOOL BOY 1 (CONT’D) What do you say to the weather, now?

dialogues.speaker: SCHOOL BOY 2
dialogues.text: I say the weather will do.  Blue Revisions dated 11th June 2012 5A.

dialogues.speaker: SCHOOL BOY 3
dialogues.text: I say doubtful!

dialogues.speaker: SCHOOL BOY 2
dialogues.text: I say - bad!  Blue Revisions dated 11th June 2012 6. NELLY’s hand silently stills the absent tap of an ERRANT SCHOOLBOY’s foot against his chair as he sits ina makeshift prompt box close by.

dialogues.speaker: NELLY
dialogues.text: (shouting out) A little louder if you please John. The SCHOOL CONDUCTOR NODS to a KEEN VIOLINIST, BOW AT THE

dialogues.speaker: SCHOOL BOY 2
dialogues.text: I can see for myself that there's a storm coming. THEN he nods to a LARGE SCHOOLBOY who rattles a metal sto sheet, whilst the JOLLY PERCUSSIONIST turns a wind drum, and a THIRD SCHOOLBOY SHIFTS a TIN OF PEAS, building in momentum like icy drops of sleeting rain, all just visibl in the makeshift wings. SCHOOL BOY 2 (CONT’D) I smell the snow- The RISING SOUNDS of percussive storm LOUDER NOW- SCHOOL BOY 2 (CONT’D) ...-I feel the hurricane, in the air. TWO SCHOOLBOY MOUNTAINEERS cross the stage, joining the cafe scene

dialogues.speaker: SCHOOL BOY 3
dialogues.text: Well are you ready at last? The BACK AND FORTH OF THE METAL STORM TRAY RATTLING, THE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The TEARING STEADY RHYTHM OF TRAIN WHEELS AGAINST STEEL A

dialogues.speaker: TRACK-
dialogues.text: The STREAK of countryside, FLEETING and ABSTRACTED, a BLU of light and colour beyond.

dialogues.speaker: SCHOOL BOY 4 VO
dialogues.text: I am sick and weary of all this delay Then just visible in the glass, NELLY[mid 20's] reflectio indistinct yet rippling in the glass-  Blue Revisions dated 11th June 2012 7.

dialogues.speaker: SCHOOL BOY 3 VO
dialogues.text: You hear what my friend says? Do you cross the mountain with us or not?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: NELLY, seemingly lost in watching the play, oblivious to BENHAM'’s brief gaze, quietly observant, noting little to give away her state of distraction bar the steam of her w boots and the sense that her mind is always elsewhere-

dialogues.speaker: SCHOOL BOY 3
dialogues.text: Fair weather or foul, I have no time to lose. And I am for pushing on- But still BENHAM clocks it, looking back, resuming watchi The SCHOOL BOY MOUTAINEERS climbing a mountainous pile of plaster and cardboard Alp. The endless icy landscape beyo and SWIRL of the PERCUSSIVE STORM DEAFENING IN THE

dialogues.speaker: ORCHESTRA PIT-
dialogues.text: A YOUNG PERCUSSIONIST SWILLS peas in a tin tray, creating noise of falling rain. It builds and builds- ALL carrying NELLY far away, deep within her mind-

dialogues.speaker: POURING RAIN-
dialogues.text: The impressive Manchester Free Trade hall looming above- The TURN of WHEELS over wet cobbles-— The STEAMING FLANK OF HORSES, HOOVES TREADING WET COBBLES

dialogues.speaker: THEY PULL A CARRIAGE TO A STILL-
dialogues.text: FINGERS REACHING UP to UNFASTEN a carriage door, CHARLEY DICKENS [18 yrs] stands holding an umbrella waiting- A young NELLY [18 yrs] steps down from the carriage to be greeted by CHARLEY, holding up the umbrella, trying to sh her from the pouring rain.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLEY
dialogues.text: (holding out a hand) Miss Ellen, welcome. I am Charley Dickens. Welcome to Manchester. NELLY smiles, suddenly a glove clasped in her hand falls the ground. CHARLEY at once bends down picks it up.  Blue Revisions dated 11th June 2012 8.

dialogues.speaker: NELLY
dialogues.text: Thank you.. Behind NELLY, MRS FRANCES TERNAN [late 40’s] NELLY’s moth bright, lively woman peering out into the grey of Manches life.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLEY
dialogues.text: Welcome..Welcome..Mrs Ternan.

dialogues.speaker: MRS TERNAN
dialogues.text: Charley, thank you. So wet.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLEY
dialogues.text: Yes, do be careful. MARIA TERNAN [20 yrs] NELLY’s sister smiling clutching a box-

dialogues.speaker: CHARLEY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Miss Maria. Come inside..Come inside.. The SWAY of CRINOLINE skimming the rainy pavements-

dialogues.speaker: CHARLEY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: My father is waiting. The others are already here. What a day! NELLY, MRS TERNAN guided by CHARLEY towards the entrance the Free Trade hall passing a poster advertising-— The Frozen Deep by Mr. Wilkie Collins. Under the manageme of Mr. Charles Dickens clearly visible on a billboard overhead-

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: Nelly, look- MARIA beaming, eyes searching the poster, at last finding Frances Ternan, Miss Maria Ternan, Miss Ellen Ternan. NEL MARIA and MRS TERNAN peering at the poster with quiet awe

dialogues.speaker: NELLY
dialogues.text: Yes, there we are.

dialogues.speaker: MRS TERNAN
dialogues.text: The print is a little small, but no matter. CHARLEY beyond waiting. MRS TERNAN ushering MARIA and NELLY inside. Their bonnets and skirts a flash of colour against the grey of Manchester life all around-  10 Blue Revisions dated 11th June 2012 9.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CHARLEY leading the trio of women along an impressive woo lined corridor. Chairs stacked either side. He leads them through into-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The opulent and magnificent interior of the Free Trade Hall- Paintings of the Kings and Queens of England flank one si of the wall as CHARLEY leads them towards- A beautiful theatre in the final moments of construction the far end of the vast hall. CARPENTERS, STAGE MANAGEMEN GASLIGHT ENGINEERS working around the distant figure of CHARLES DICKENS [mid 40’s] lost in directing the STAGE HA and STAGE MANAGEMENT in placing the scenery on the stage.

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: Yes..Yes..If we could have the flat over there..We need to create as much space as possible. .We’1l probably have to bring everyting to the left..What worked at Tavistock house will seem lost here..Our set looks like a toy theatre if we do not- CHARLEY leading NELLY, MRS TERNAN and MARIA towards the s

dialogues.speaker: CHARLEY
dialogues.text: Father- DICKENS turns and at once he is lost behind a huge flat o painted rocks being manoeuvered into place on the stage. the scenery has past, he is revealed. He jumps down from stage, springing across the hall, smiling, arms outstretc delighting in their arrival-

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: At last we have a full company! Mrs Ternan welcome.

dialogues.speaker: MRS TERNAN
dialogues.text: Mr Dickens. (surveying theatre) What a beautiful theatre you have built for us.

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: We have tried. I am glad. Welcome Miss Maria..A good journey I hope?  Blue Revisions dated 11th June 2012 10.

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: Yes..Yes..Mr Dickens. Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: MRS TERNAN
dialogues.text: It was quite comfortable.

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: Good. Good. And you must be Miss Ellen Ternan. DICKENS stops, mid way through shaking their hands, pausi on NELLY, with a smile.

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You’ve met my eldest son Charley of course.

dialogues.speaker: NELLY
dialogues.text: Yes..yes..He very kindly rescued my glove.

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: Ah, the gallant chevalier! DICKENS grips CHARLEY’s shoulder in passing, turning to present them to the MEMBERS of the COMPANY-

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Ladies and gentleman may we welcome our newcomer, Miss Ellen who is helping us in our hour of need. (to NELLY) We wish your sister Frances well. Is it the Haymarket or Phoenix we have lost her to?

dialogues.speaker: NELLY
dialogues.text: The Haymarket. She is so sad not to be here.

dialogues.speaker: MRS TERNAN
dialogues.text: But Nelly will give you a wonderful performance-

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: I have no doubt. DICKENS smiles, the MEMBERS of the company on the approac welcoming. DICKENS, in a spiral of energy, enthusiastical enjoying the performance of these introductions-—

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Now Maria, Mrs Ternan you know everyone from our previous rehearsals..  Blue Revisions dated 11th June 2012 11.

dialogues.speaker: MRS TERNAN
dialogues.text: Yes..Yes..I remember..Some familiar faces. I remember.

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: Miss Ellen may I introduce you to our family of actors- MR EGG[early 40’s]MR LEMON [mid 40’s] and MISS SABINE [ea 30’s]smiling and shaking hands, surrounding MRS TERNAN, N and MARIA.

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Mr Lemon, Mr Egg, Miss Sabine...Mr Berger, our brilliant young composer-— MR BERGER [mid 20’s] amongst the SWELL of welcoming actor

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Mr Evans, Mr Piggot..I would like to introduce you to our author Mr Collins- DICKENS looks beyond, eyes searching with wry irritation-

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: But as ever he is late..And of course some of my own family- MAMEY DICKENS [17 yrs] and KATEY DICKENS [16 yrs] DICKENS eldest daughters and GEORGINA HOGARTH [early/mid 30's] CATHERINE’s SISTER close by-

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: My daughters Mamey, Katey and my sister in law Miss Georgina Hogarth. And here is- DICKENS rounding up four boys FRANK [13 yrs], ALFRED[12 y SYDNEY [10 yrs] HENRY DICKENS [8 yrs] tapping their heads with percussive aplomb on every name-

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Frank- (tap) Alfred- (tap) Sydney- (tap) Henry.... (tap) Where is youngest boy-? EDWARD ‘PLORN’ DICKENS [5 yrs] nervously peers out from behind DICKENS, DICKENS mock searching behind his coat ta  11 Blue Revisions dated 11th June 2012 12.

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Plorn. Don’t hide there. DICKENS at once scoops PLORN up in his arms, smiling. NEL watching enchanted, the names and faces already a blur.

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: And that is it..I think..And..of course, my wife- Beyond, CATHERINE DICKENS [early 40’s] DICKENS’ wife, hea and swollen seated someway off. NELLY looks over, their e briefly meeting.

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Now I suggest maybe in half an hour..Is that enough time ladies to settle your bonnets..? - I would like to rehearse- DICKENS just seeing-

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: ..-but without our author- WILKIE COLLINS[mid 30’s] DICKENS colleague and friend run towards him, from across the hall, tripping over his bags with fashionable aplomb-

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Mr Collins..Who is at last here! Why is it I am waiting for you, Wilkie? Why must you always be late? COLLINS in smiling greeting, embracing DICKENS-

dialogues.speaker: COLLINS
dialogues.text: Because it irritates you, Charles, and it amuses me to see you in bad temper!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The SET and THEATRE now fully installed. A few STAGE HAND finishing off small bits of carpentry and adjusting set. set now lit with oil lamps. The ACTORS wait on stage, finding their positions. NELLY amongst them, ushered by MRS TERNAN into place. Downstage, to one side, DICKENS and WILKIE in whispered debate-  Blue Revisions dated 11th June 2012 13.

dialogues.speaker: COLLINS
dialogues.text: I cannot see a scene we can afford to lose, Charles. DICKENS pen in hand, mapping out potential cuts on a page the script-

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: But it is too long. And it will bore if it is too long. It was too long in London and it will be too long in Manchester. Though it pains me... Wilkie- DICKENS hands the script back to COLLINS, offering him a at his suggested cuts, his gaze direct.

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Cut.Cut.Cut. COLLINS throws his hands up exasperated but concedes, sco ferociously through the text with his pencil.

dialogues.speaker: COLLINS
dialogues.text: It is done! It is done! (hushed) You may tell Mr Egg he has lost his last soliloquy.

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: (hushed) You must do it. As author I shall not deny you that.

dialogues.speaker: COLLINS
dialogues.text: You are insufferable. DICKENS scribbles more on the script, then hands it once back to COLLINS.

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: And here..And here..

dialogues.speaker: COLLINS
dialogues.text: Butcher! DICKENS smiles, walks to centre stage to address the comp of ACTORS-

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: Now everyone please be careful.- Our little theatre is not yet complete- DICKENS nods to MR STANFIELD giving a finishing touch to set, paintbrush in hand.  Blue Revisions dated 11th June 2012 14.

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: And as we are rehearsing Miss Ellen in today let us be considerate. I am keen to review the last act, just the final entry of Wardour and Aldersly so places friends. (directing MARIA) Maria, if we could have you over there. DICKENS gently positions MARIA, moving back across the stage-

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: And-? DICKENS’ eyes graze over NELLY mildly lost, awaiting direction.

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: We have the ladies in a group over here. Miss Ellen..Mrs Ternan.

dialogues.speaker: MRS TERNAN
dialogues.text: Just over here, Nelly dearest. Mr Dickens may I suggest the women are positioned a little further upstage?

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: Yes..Let us have you here.

dialogues.speaker: MRS TERNAN
dialogues.text: Thank you. MRS TERNAN nods to NELLY to follow her, taking their positions in a small cluster close by.

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: Should I stand a little wider?

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: Yes, very good, Maria..But not too far, for it is your face and not mine that will be holding the attention of our audience I feel sure.

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Where’s Collins? COLLINS looks up, from his script, both actor and writer, hurrying onto the stage.  Blue Revisions dated 11th June 2012 15.

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I will need you standing close to the rear if I am to carry you in, Wilkie. You're ready?

dialogues.speaker: COLLINS
dialogues.text: (hurrying off) No..Yes..Yes. COLLINS disappears behind a flat, then puts his head back around- COLLINS (CONT’D) Should you not come? I cannot carry myself. NELLY smiles, enjoying the banter as DICKENS disappears o to the side of the wings.

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: Of course..yes..Yes. (pointing to CHARLEY) Charley, there, relax the arms. A little less stiff. CHARLEY nods, taking his place, DICKENS disappearing once more off stage. MUTTERINGS and THEN- NELLY looking down at her part on sides of paper in her h

dialogues.speaker: NELLY
dialogues.text: (aside to MRS TERNAN) Do I speak after the gun? SUDDENLY DICKENS enters carrying COLLINS -

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: Frank!..Frank!! MARIA raises her hands to her face, looking suitably alarmed.

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: Then my line...Saved, Saved for you!

dialogues.speaker: COLLINS
dialogues.text: Don’t you put me down here? DICKENS releases COLLINS, MARIA now cradling COLLINS in her arms.

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: He's footsore and weary, Clara. But I have saved him..And so on..and so on..  Blue Revisions dated 11th June 2012 16. DICKENS gestures for MR LEMON to step forward.

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (pointing) Yes, there very good. Then your line Wilkie- COLLINS looks up as all crowd around him.

dialogues.speaker: COLLINS
dialogues.text: Where is Wardour?! Help him! Never mind me! DICKENS already on the floor now, in dying pose.

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: (to MR LEMON) Mark, this is when you see me. MR LEMON falls at DICKENS feet.

dialogues.speaker: MR LEMON
dialogues.text: Wardour! Dear Wardour! Old friend whom I have wronged, remember and forgive me.

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: Very good. You are forgiven.

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Then the scene plays as is. DICKENS directing from his dying pose.

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Do not be afraid to project. We have over 2,000 seats. (shouting out) Catherine, do say if you cannot hear us. CATHERINE just visible perched on a seat looks up, not listening, somewhat bemused. CLOSE by her sister GEORGINA and the DICKENS CHILDREN, watching appreciatively.

dialogues.speaker: CATHERINE
dialogues.text: (distracted) What?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGINA
dialogues.text: (calling back) We can hear you very well, Charles.  Blue Revisions dated 11th June 2012 17.

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: Very good. Everyone speak up. Maria, you take me in your arms.

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: Richard, dear Richard, look at your old playmate.

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: Then music-— MR BERGER at the piano to the side of the stage, begins t play-

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Not yet Berger. I am just marking through the cues... which lasts until the curtain has fallen by which time I am nearly dead. Then we kiss. Then gun. BANG! Then- (looking to NELLY) Epilogue-? NELLY looks up, in waiting-

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Epilogue. NELLY walks forward a little, clutching a few pages of script.

dialogues.speaker: NELLY
dialogues.text: This is a tale of woe. This is a tale of sorrow. A love denied. A love restored to live beyond tomorrow. Lest we think silence is the place to hide a heavy heart, remember to love and be loved is life itself. Without which we are nought. NELLY quietly captivating, a little nervous yet oddly touching, DICKENS momentarily lost until-

dialogues.speaker: MRS TERNAN
dialogues.text: (hushed aside) Maybe a little louder, Nelly. DICKENS turns, addresses all-

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: The curtain closes. Loud applause. Yet audible the crying of 2,000. Bravo. Bravo. I suggest a full dress rehearsal in two hours time. Thank you gentleman-  12 Blue Revisions dated 11th June 2012 18. DICKENS eyes flick to NELLY.

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Thank you ladies. The COMPANY of ACTORS already dissolving, lost in their conversation as they head off to dressing rooms and costu fittings.

dialogues.speaker: COLLINS
dialogues.text: Oh Charles, your last speech I think could benefit from cutting.

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: You think so?

dialogues.speaker: COLLINS
dialogues.text: I do.

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: (deflecting) Catherine-? CATHERINE looks up barely listening.

dialogues.speaker: COLLINS
dialogues.text: Shall we discuss it?

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: Yes. Later. COLLINS, shakes his head, concedes. DICKENS reaches for a small flask of brandy in his coat pocket, swigs, sees NEL alone, the Arctic landscape behind.

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (almost to himself) She has something. COLLINS noting DICKENS quiet distraction, looking on. NEL disappearing into the scenery of the Frozen Deep.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A weeping MARIA, her face stained with tears, DICKENS in arms, swathed in rags, beard, grey and powdery, dying in MARIA’s arms, illuminated on stage by a row of lit gaslig as the play comes to its end. MR LEMON kneels down close to a dying DICKENS as he lies MARIA’s arms, her body shuddering with tears. DICKENS reaches out a hand, patting MR LEMON’s arm in fin embrace.  13 14 Blue Revisions dated 11th June 2012 19.

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: Come nearer! My mind clears, but my eyes grow dim. You will remember me kindly for Frank's sake? Poor Frank! Why does he hide his face? MR EGG looks away, his face streaming with tears.

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Is he crying? Just seen beyond in the wings, some of the ACTORS and STAGEHANDS watching, NELLY amongst them, all held in the absolute moment, NELLY watching DICKENS with a quiet intensity-

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Nearer Clara - I want to look my last at you. My sister, Clara! Kiss me Sister, kiss me before I die. MARIA kisses DICKENS- Just visible in the wings, a STAGE HAND sets light to gunpowder, mimicking the blast of a ships gun/cannon. NELLY, lost in DICKENS’ performance, oblivious to the curtain sweeping closed-

dialogues.speaker: MRS TERNAN
dialogues.text: (urgent/hushed in passing) Nelly..Nelly.. NELLY hurries on stage, to deliver her epilogue.

dialogues.speaker: THUNDEROUS APPLAUSE-
dialogues.text: DICKENS, arms outstretched at the front of the stage, leading his cast in triumphant encore- MARIA flushed and beaming, DICKENS presenting her centre stage- NELLY looking on, bashfully happy. She sees DICKENS smiling at her down the line.

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS, FINGERS TREMULOUS ON PIANO KEYS-
dialogues.text: Blue Revisions dated 11th June 2012 20.

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: .«-Queen Victoria... DICKENS BANGS HIS FINGERS ON THE KEYS.

dialogues.speaker: COLLINS
dialogues.text: Prince Albert of Saxe-Coburg and Gothanburg!

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: King Leopold I of Belgium!

dialogues.speaker: COLLINS
dialogues.text: Prince Frederick!

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: Hans Christian Anderson!

dialogues.speaker: COLLINS
dialogues.text: William Thackeray!!!

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: No, No I am sorry, it is not enough that we should play before these mere mortals... DICKENS smiles, his audience enwrapped as he once more

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: It is Manchester who have given us the highest accolade. It is Manchester whose approval I have looked to. And it is Manchester who has surely bestowed tonight's success. Friends we are victorious! And at once DICKENS and COLLINS playing, a madcap, joyful duet. MISS SABINE hovering close by. Yet DICKENS too busy for anyone is lost in fun, playing on with COLLINS as all break into lively spontaneous dancing. MAMEY and KATEY, GEORGINA HOGARTH in the mix. MR LEMON scoops up NELLY in passing. NELLY laughing, lost in a mad dance with MARIA and OTHERS. DICKENS, knocking back another drink, foot silently tapping against the floor, quietly revelling. His eyes briefly meet with NELLY, both lost in the sheer joy of it all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 15 Blue Revisions dated 11th June 2012 21. DICKENS suddenly stands, behind MR EGG, moving his arms and legs almost as if a puppet master with his puppet.

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Come come, Augustus you must dance and have no notion of walking. Mr EGG reluctantly concedes as DICKENS forces him, gaily onto the dance floor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The ENTIRE COMPANY gathered around the piano. BERGER play Three Fishes as they sing. DICKENS at the heart, enjoying company in full song.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: NELLY stands to one side of the room, flushed and exhausted. DICKENS stands performing some kind of mesmerizing/ hypnosis trick on MISS SABINE who sits opposite DICKENS, making the room still as he works with MISS SABINE

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: Now raise your arms Miss Sabine. Very slowly. MISS SABINE raises her arms, all compelled to watch.

dialogues.speaker: NELLY
dialogues.text: It is remarkable. NELLY looks up, sees CATHERINE, standing on the periphery.

dialogues.speaker: CATHERINE
dialogues.text: (with a smile) One of his magic tricks. CATHERINE’s eyes graze over NELLY, letting an awkward silence hang- CATHERINE (CONT’D) You are an admirer of my husband's work, Miss Ternan?

dialogues.speaker: NELLY
dialogues.text: (nods ) Yes of course. At the moment I am lost in Little Dorrit. It has a darker heart perhaps. Though I am gripped between laughter and heartbreak. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 16 Blue Revisions dated 11th June 2012 22.

dialogues.speaker: NELLY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Until now I thought Bleak House was the novel that would stay with me the most. It has this alarming spirit of unease. Lady Deadlock haunted by her past..I am drawn back to those pages again and again. And yet there is so much that also makes me smile.

dialogues.speaker: CATHERINE
dialogues.text: It is a fiction designed to entertain.

dialogues.speaker: NELLY
dialogues.text: No..no..surely it’s more than that. It makes us think. It changes us. CATHERINE considers NELLY, with thoughtful gaze then look back at DICKENS, a sudden heavy sadness overwhelming her which she deflects witha smile-

dialogues.speaker: CATHERINE
dialogues.text: He will be up all night and cross all day. CATHERINE moves off, clearly heading to bed. CATHERINE (CONT’D) Good night, Miss Ternan.

dialogues.speaker: NELLY
dialogues.text: Good night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: NELLY looks back at DICKENS, MISS SABINE now hypnotised and dancing a jig or the like, the party in uproar, DICKENS at the helm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is nearly dawn, the fire is low and the gas lamps now out. DICKENS sunk amongst the company of ACTORS; some dozing, some listening enwrapped, some searching the wine bottles for the last dregs of wine. MRS TERNAN wide eyed is now being mesmerised by DICKENS.

dialogues.speaker: MRS TERNAN
dialogues.text: There are too many cats..too many cats and not enough birds.. I need wings. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Blue Revisions dated 11th June 2012 23.

dialogues.speaker: MRS TERNAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Hold the baby..hold the baby..No..No..She has gone...With no wings..Where is she?..Where is she?..Is she safe?...Please tell me she is safe. MRS TERNAN transfixed, her face etched with shock and ter the whole room held, watching her. DICKENS smiles, a litt uneasy.

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: Ah- DICKENS smiles, unsure, then he squeezes MRS TERNAN’s hands, releasing her back to reality.

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: And now you are back with us, Mrs Ternan. MRS TERNAN coming to, exhales.

dialogues.speaker: MRS TERNAN
dialogues.text: I am back where? MARIA grips her hands, close to her.

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: Mother..Mother..I think you remembered Fanny. On the boat.

dialogues.speaker: MRS TERNAN
dialogues.text: What did I say?

dialogues.speaker: NELLY
dialogues.text: (close to) You were trying to save her, mother.

dialogues.speaker: MRS TERNAN
dialogues.text: I am sorry Mr Dickens. I think I have strayed into some family history.

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: Indeed? The whole COMPANY leaning forward, listening, unsure wher this is leading-

dialogues.speaker: MRS TERNAN
dialogues.text: My eldest daughter Fanny was thrown from her cot when my husband and I were touring in America some years ago. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Blue Revisions dated 11th June 2012 24.

dialogues.speaker: MRS TERNAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: We were on a paddle steamer which was rammed by another boat. She was saved, miraculously between two mattresses.

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: The angels were watching.

dialogues.speaker: NELLY
dialogues.text: They were. DICKENS moved by the closeness of these women, together, smiling at MRS TERNAN. She relaxes.

dialogues.speaker: MRS TERNAN
dialogues.text: I am done Mr Dickens. MRS TERNAN slightly thrown, gathering herself to stand.

dialogues.speaker: COLLINS
dialogues.text: As am I. An extraordinary story. COLLINS finishes up the last of the wine, steering himsel wearily to bed, picking up his shoes and jacket on route- COLLINS (CONT’D) Tomorrow and tomorrow and tomorrow. COLLINS pats DICKENS back affectionately in passing- COLLINS (CONT’D) Good night. The ACTORS stagger off to bed, a sense of good nights all round.

dialogues.speaker: MR EGG
dialogues.text: Five o’clock. Bed. NELLY lingers at the window. She pulls back the shutter, a thin shaft of dawn light searing through-

dialogues.speaker: ALL
dialogues.text: Good night- NELLY, MARIA and MRS TERNAN the last to leave.

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: You were quite wonderful tonight, Maria. (to all/ ie MARIA) I did try to console her in hushed aside but all she could whisper is ‘0! So sad. O! It is so sad!'Such a good pale little face.  Blue Revisions dated 11th June 2012 25. DICKENS cups MARIA’s face, kissing her gently on the forehead, a little drunk and heady from too much wine.

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: I am afraid I couldn’t stop the tears. You were too good.

dialogues.speaker: MRS TERNAN
dialogues.text: You will not find a better Clara. MARIA smiles, following MRS TERNAN out-—

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: Thank you Mama.

dialogues.speaker: MRS TERNAN
dialogues.text: Now I must take these angels to bed. (almost to self/ looking at girls) So precious. MRS TERNAN and MARIA go to exit.

dialogues.speaker: NELLY
dialogues.text: (as goes) I could stay up all night. I am too awake to sleep. NELLY walks towards the window.

dialogues.speaker: NELLY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: There is daylight. From beyond-

dialogues.speaker: MRS TERNAN
dialogues.text: (calling back) Nelly dearest, we all need sleep. NELLY makes to go, DICKENS, one finger pulling back the curtain peering out.

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: This is my favourite time. When the day is creeping up on us- NELLY hesitates, caught between staying and going. She crosses the room, stands by the window opposite him, following his gaze.

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: .-and we must put in order the chaos of the night. Stand guard once more, ready for life.  17 Blue Revisions dated 11th June 2012 26. Outside STREET URCHINS jostle for meat scraps, as the MEAT PACKERS unload carcasses from a cart, ready for market. A PROSTITUTE heads home, clearly a little worse the wear from the night before. A COUPLE embrace in the shadows.

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: A wonderful fact to reflect upon, that every human creature is a profound secret and mystery to every other.

dialogues.speaker: NELLY
dialogues.text: Until that secret is given to another to look after. Then perhaps two human creatures may know each other. (beat) Do you not think so? NELLY’s directness suddenly piercing DICKENS but he defle

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: Has Mrs Dickens gone to bed?

dialogues.speaker: NELLY
dialogues.text: Some time ago. He finishes up his drink, lost deep within himself.

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: She has such terrible headaches. (beat) Sleep.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The glow of an oil lamp- NELLY’s reflection refracted in a dressing table mirror a she dresses for dinner. The fall of an earring, a wrist dabbed with perfume, lightly pressed against her neck. GEORGE hovers close by grappling with his shirt cuff and cufflink-

dialogues.speaker: NELLY
dialogues.text: Pull it taut- NELLY goes to help him, pulling the cuff taut, and threading it neatly through-

dialogues.speaker: NELLY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Upright like a brigadier and then.. GEORGE watches her, clearly a familiar act, his breath wa on hers.  18 Blue Revisions dated 11th June 2012 27.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Thank you. NELLY nods, resumes dressing, GEORGE watching her-

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Were you on the beach again today? Miss Brooke thought she saw you. GEORGE sinks on the bed, leaning forward to lace his shoe

dialogues.speaker: NELLY
dialogues.text: Yes. GEORGE waits for more. NELLY already slipping away from him, remote once more. He hesitates, looks down at NELLY’s shoes close by. He picks one up, tips it a little, a pool of sand just visible, grazing the insole. GEORGE considers, with quiet concern. INT. PARLOUR/LIBRARY. SCHOOLHOUSE. MARGATE. NIGHT. 1885. The aftermath of a pleasant if small dinner party, a GOVERNOR and his WIFE, LAMBOURNE and his YOUNG WIFE, REVEREND BENHAM and GEORGE hosting and happy at the helm. tray of sweet wine and tea close by. A fire burning in th grate and the oil lamps lit.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: I was just showing Malcolm- GEORGE lost in conversation with the GOVERNOR a copy of A Tale of Two Cities in his hand, leaning against a bookshe

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: See it is signed. NELLY passes around tea, topping up a glass here or there

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Apparently he modelled the character of Lucie Manette on Nelly.The families were very close when Nelly was a child.

dialogues.speaker: NELLY
dialogues.text: George, please. I am sure he drew inspiration from many people. Our guests do not wish to be bored with-  Blue Revisions dated 11th June 2012 27A.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: My wife adores his novels. Of course he’s often very funny but...I find a little bleak. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Blue Revisions dated 11th June 2012 28.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: One wonders what demons raged in his mind.

dialogues.speaker: BENHAM
dialogues.text: Indeed.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Thackeray, now there’s a writer.

dialogues.speaker: NELLY
dialogues.text: You can’t compare them.

dialogues.speaker: BENHAM
dialogues.text: Oh I agree. I am for Mr Dickens. There are times that I have envied Mrs Wharton Robinson to have known him- even as a child. NELLY thoughtful, BENHAM animated sipping on his after dinner wine.

dialogues.speaker: BENHAM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: A true humanitarian, wittily observant yet burning with a political bonfire that elevates and brings urgency to his work. A writer- yes, at times bleak, but one who makes us laugh at our own absurdity. We see ourselves clearly in all our folly. Yes, he is still with us! NELLY suddenly stands, the scrape of her chair, sudden an surprising, blowing out a candle on a table.

dialogues.speaker: NELLY
dialogues.text: Thank you Mr Benham. NELLY fiddles, intent on getting the nub of the waxed candle out.

dialogues.speaker: BENHAM
dialogues.text: It is a subject in which I sometimes run away with myself. BENHAM’s eyes dart to NELLY.

dialogues.speaker: BENHAM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: As Mrs Wharton Robinson knows only too well. BENHAM looks to NELLY, offering conciliatory smile.

dialogues.speaker: GOVERNOR
dialogues.text: Run away....Run away..I for one am determined to revisit him immediately. Where would you suggest I begin?  Blue Revisions dated 11th June 2012 28A.

dialogues.speaker: LAMBOURNE
dialogues.text: Martin Chuzzlewit.  Blue Revisions dated 11th June 2012 29.

dialogues.speaker: BENHAM
dialogues.text: Yes..Of course..So many to choose from. Where to start? Any novel but for brief pleasure I would suggest browsing through a copy of Dickens weekly literary magazine- NELLY turns back to see BENHAM peering at a copy of Household Words, A printed journal composed by Charles Dickens, one of several on a shelf.

dialogues.speaker: BENHAM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Household words. A collection of many of his writings and indeed chapters of his novels. I am sure Mrs Wharton Robinson would not mind if you cared to borrow-

dialogues.speaker: NELLY
dialogues.text: Of course. Of course.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: My wife has nearly every edition. We have run out of shelves. MARY enters with more refreshment-

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Ah good. Thank you Mary. They nod their thanks in passing, GEORGE once more drawin the GOVERNOR and his WIFE into conversation. BENHAM reach for a copy of the Frozen Deep playtext-

dialogues.speaker: BENHAM
dialogues.text: The Frozen Deep. You have the text of Mr Collins’ play? NELLY turns, suddenly on edge. BENHAM’s eyes already graz over several notes made in some folded pages slipped betw the pages of the playtext. On these papers, the lines are scored through, the sense of this as a once worked text. just visible, pressed in the folds of the these pages- A tiny lock of hair.

dialogues.speaker: NELLY
dialogues.text: Yes. It is not a good play. NELLY with gentle precision, takes the playtext out of BENHAM’s hands, snapping it shut and sliding it once more into the shelf.

dialogues.speaker: NELLY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: But I will find you one. BENHAM oddly thrown, yet trying to gather himself, curiosity stirred as NELLY’s eyes search the titles.  Blue Revisions dated 11th June 2012 29A.

dialogues.speaker: NELLY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (beat) David Copperfield. For our reading?  Blue Revisions dated 11th June 2012 30.

dialogues.speaker: BENHAM
dialogues.text: Will you walk again tomorrow?

dialogues.speaker: NELLY
dialogues.text: (beat) Perhaps.

dialogues.speaker: BENHAM
dialogues.text: May I join you? NELLY hesitates, pulling a text down from a shelf, seemingly distracted.

dialogues.speaker: NELLY
dialogues.text: I walk at quite a pace.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: NELLY brushes her hair, GEORGE undressing close by. Both silent, neither able to make the first move. Suddenly, NELLY turns on him.

dialogues.speaker: NELLY
dialogues.text: Why must you do that? Flaunt my connection? It is dull.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Dull to have known Charles Dickens? GEORGE looks at NELLY, with a quizzical smile.

dialogues.speaker: NELLY
dialogues.text: I was a child. NELLY climbs into bed next to him.

dialogues.speaker: NELLY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Yet to refer to him as bleak. It is a misconception-

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: What? I do not understand what you are talking of, Nelly. This constant agitation.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Nelly- NELLY deflects turning to wind the clock on the bedside table.

dialogues.speaker: NELLY
dialogues.text: I am just tired.  20 21 Blue Revisions dated 11th June 2012 31.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Darkness- NELLY, eyes flickering closed, on top of GEORGE, the stea rise and fall of her naked back as she grips him, lost in lovemaking, intense and connected with GEORGE until reach shuddering climax, GEORGE looks at her, a sense of her fl ahead without him- NELLY, sated, leans forward, the moment dissolving across face. GEORGE tenderly cups the back of her head and neck with t palm of his hand, his lips close to her cheek, the warmth of her breath on his neck, the rhythm sobering. They lie, GEORGE turns, looks for her, NELLY’s eyes closed.

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS VO
dialogues.text: It was a murky confusion - here and there blotted with a colour like the colour of the smoke from damp fuel- INT. ORCHESTRA GALLERY. ST MARTIN’S HALL. 1857. DAY. 21

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Through ornate railings, NELLY, MARIA, MRS TERNAN and FANNY TERNAN [ early 20’s] NELLY’s older pretty sister, silently peering down- DICKENS mid reading, addresses a packed AUDIENCE, lost in performance. His eyes briefly graze NELLY’s, a flicker of surprise, quickly dismissed as he resumes intense, hunche over the podium.

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: As we struggled on, nearer and nearer to the sea, from which this mighty wind was blowing dead on shore, its force became more and more terrific.. The AUDIENCE enwrapped, NELLY tightly gripping the programme for DICKENS reading of David Copperfield.

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Long before we saw the sea, its Spray was on our lips, and showered salt rain upon us.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: NELLY grips the handrail, leaning towards DICKENS, eyes fixed.  22 Blue Revisions dated 11th June 2012 32.

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: As the receding wave swept back with a hoarse roar, it seemed to scoop out deep caves in the beach, as if its purpose were to undermine the earth.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: DICKENS stalking the stage, papers in hand, captivating t

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Another cry arose on shore; and looking to the wreck, we saw the cruel sail, with blow on blow, beat off the lower of the two men, and fly up in triumph round the active figure left alone upon the mast.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: DICKENS eyes briefly graze over his AUDIENCE, hesitating seeing NELLY-

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: At length Ham neared the wreck. He was so near that with one more of his vigorous strokes he would be clinging to it, -when, a green vast hillside of water, moving on shoreward, from beyond the ship, he seemed to leap up into it with a mighty bound and the ship was gone.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: NELLY sinks back in her seat, cheeks flushed, exhausted y exhilarated, as if she has been in the very same storm.

dialogues.speaker: APPLAUSE-
dialogues.text: DICKENS comes to, as if out of a trance, exhausted, the life blood almost seeped out of him. INT. AUDITORIUM. ST MARTIN’S HALL. 1857. DAY. 22 DICKENS with COLLINS consumed by a throng of VICTORIAN LADIES, a swell of DIGNITARIES waiting to usher him away-

dialogues.speaker: VICTORIAN LADY
dialogues.text: Truly Mr. Dickens it is never so alive as when it is spoken by its author.  Blue Revisions dated 11th June 2012 33. DICKENS eyes catching on NELLY with MRS TERNAN, FANNY and MARIA.

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: (calling over) Mrs Ternan. (to VICTORIAN LADY) Excuse me. DICKENS hurrying to catch up, desperately trying to leave the constant WELL WISHERS and FANS behind-

dialogues.speaker: MRS TERNAN
dialogues.text: Mr. Dickens, it was remarkable. Such control, such mastery in your performance. The WOMEN swarm, DICKENS standing happily amongst them.

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: (hushed) I am told these readings double sales.

dialogues.speaker: LAUGHTER-
dialogues.text: DICKENS eyes dart to NELLY, in waiting-

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: It was quite brilliant, Mr Dickens.

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: It was?

dialogues.speaker: FANNY
dialogues.text: Absolutely.

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: Miss Frances. We have missed you.

dialogues.speaker: FANNY
dialogues.text: Not enough it seems. NELLY flushes, FANNY squeezing NELLY with sisterly pride. DICKENS charmed by this, MRS TERNAN smiles, deflecting.

dialogues.speaker: MRS TERNAN
dialogues.text: Mrs Dickens is not here today?

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: No, not today.  LAUGHTER. Blue Revisions dated 11th June 2012 34.

dialogues.speaker: MRS TERNAN
dialogues.text: What a pity! To have missed it. You have blown us all off course. What a storm! It was as if we were on the heath with Lear. DICKENS smiles, yet he looks to NELLY, eyes quietly searching.

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: It did not disappoint?

dialogues.speaker: NELLY
dialogues.text: Well- DICKENS hesitates, latching on to NELLY’s words, like a dog with a bone.

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: I do not like ‘well’. NELLY flushes, urged on by her giggling sisters.

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: Nelly has read every chapter twice.

dialogues.speaker: NELLY
dialogues.text: Yes but-

dialogues.speaker: FANNY
dialogues.text: Nelly, Mr Dickens wants to hear. NELLY wavers, caught under DICKENS’ watchful eager eye-

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: I am ready.

dialogues.speaker: NELLY
dialogues.text: ...I may have read every chapter twice but I didn’t really hear it..See it..Until now. Hearing it..Hearing you-

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: Yes. Yes.

dialogues.speaker: NELLY
dialogues.text: I felt I was in the storm..I was there... I was in it..I was on the beach with Copperfield seeing the body of his friend, drowned- (visibly struggling) It was unbearable- NELLY moved, DICKENS touched by her emotion.  Blue Revisions dated 11th June 2012 35.

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: I am glad. DICKENS delights in NELLY’s obvious connection. MRS TERNAN seeing this.

dialogues.speaker: COLLINS
dialogues.text: (calling over) Charles, come and talk to these gentlemen. I have assured them that your next novel will be your best. There is so much anticipation. They cannot wait- Nor can I! DICKENS nods, stalling for time, aware of a DIGNITARY gesturing to him across the room.

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: Where will you play next?

dialogues.speaker: NELLY
dialogues.text: We are engaged to play in Doncaster for three weeks.

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: So far away.

dialogues.speaker: MRS TERNAN
dialogues.text: It is not Australia, Mr Dickens.

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: And what are you playing? DICKENS his eyes still on NELLY-

dialogues.speaker: NELLY
dialogues.text: Two tragedies and a farce.

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: A farce!

dialogues.speaker: NELLY
dialogues.text: The Pet of the Petticoats.

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: A terrible title but- DICKENS’ smiles, making his goodbyes-—

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: «.very good races Doncaster. DICKENS already lost, almost smothered by the assembly of DIGNITARIES and ADMIRERS and JOURNALISTS waiting on his e word. DICKENS looks back, watching the departing TERNAN FAMILY, eyes searching for-  23 Blue Revisions dated 11th June 2012 36. NELLY has gone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A dark, study, heavily lined with bookshelves. DICKENS si at his desk, writing letters yet the sense of his mind elsewhere, distracted. SUDDENLY a creak of a floorboard, DICKENS looks up-

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: (calling out) Catherine- The door opens, CATHERINE stands in the doorway-

dialogues.speaker: CATHERINE
dialogues.text: Yes?

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: Shall we sit together?

dialogues.speaker: CATHERINE
dialogues.text: If you wish.

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: No..If you would prefer not..

dialogues.speaker: CATHERINE
dialogues.text: I did not sleep well last night. Perhaps I will go to bed now. DICKENS sinks, a little-

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: Yes, of course yes. CATHERINE makes to go-

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Collins has an idea for Household Words. A trip to the North. A Lazy Tour of Two Idle Apprentices. Might just be a couple of inches in it.

dialogues.speaker: CATHERINE
dialogues.text: Where will you start?

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: (beat) Doncaster. CATHERINE nods, barely listening, moving on-

dialogues.speaker: CATHERINE
dialogues.text: Turn up the lamp. You cannot write in this light.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 24 25 Blue Revisions dated 11th June 2012 37. The door closes- DICKENS sits alone, reading, staring down at the darkened page, mind clearly elsewhere.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Over DICKENS leaving his dressing room as he moves toward the bedroom. He opens the door to the bedroom, surprising CATHERINE putting on her nightdress. Her naked back. She turns, caught, alarmed. A sense of her shock and embarrassment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The SWELL of RACEGOERS breath held in anticipation and just visible amongst them- NELLY, pretty in lilac bonnet and gloves, pressed against the wooden fence, waiting. Beside her MRS TERNAN, FANNY, MARIA, DICKENS and COLLINS close by. The SOUND OF THUNDERING HORSE HOOVES galloping past building- NELLY, DICKENS, COLLINS, MRS TERNAN, FANNY and MARIA all waving and cheering madly, eyes tracking the STEAMING GLOSSY FLANKS of the horses passing in a blur, racing towards a finishing line until-

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: Nelly, it is yours. It is yours. NELLY leaps with excitement, instinctively gripping the nearest hand, DICKENS’. DICKENS cheering with delight-.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The SPILL of RACEGOERS across the racecourse, counting their winnings and lost in babbling conversation.

dialogues.speaker: NELLY
dialogues.text: Five shillings..Five shillings. COLLINS tears up his betting slip in fury, MARIA and FANNY consoling him, taking his arm, either side.

dialogues.speaker: COLLINS
dialogues.text: It was fixed. It was fixed.  Blue Revisions dated 11th June 2012 38.

dialogues.speaker: MRS TERNAN
dialogues.text: I hope you are not a bad sport, Mr Collins.

dialogues.speaker: COLLINS
dialogues.text: I’m very bad!

dialogues.speaker: MRS TERNAN
dialogues.text: Then you must win. Shall we bet again?

dialogues.speaker: COLLINS
dialogues.text: Yes. Again.

dialogues.speaker: LAUGHTER-
dialogues.text: DICKENS and NELLY follow, MRS TERNAN close behind.

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: So what will you do with your winnings, Nelly?

dialogues.speaker: NELLY
dialogues.text: I shall seek a good return on a sensible investment. NELLY smiles, teasing.

dialogues.speaker: NELLY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Or I shall spend it all at once! Though I may spend half a shilling on a copy of Household Words to be sure the two apprentices returned safely from their lazy tour.

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: They did. Though they did not want to go home.

dialogues.speaker: NELLY
dialogues.text: But what of their families?

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: They were of course missed but - DICKENS eyes catch on hers, with restless fragile intensity-

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: ...they did so enjoy being away. SUDDENLY COLLINS passes them, rounding behind DICKENS, to hurry them on.  26 27 Blue Revisions dated 11th June 2012 39.

dialogues.speaker: COLLINS
dialogues.text: We have been rumbled. (beat) You've been rumbled, Charles. COLLINS grips MRS TERNAN’s arm, urging them forward. NELLY and DICKENS hurry ahead.

dialogues.speaker: RACEGOER
dialogues.text: Mr Dickens...Mr Dickens. .How very unexpected? DICKENS stops, resigned mid footfall, smiling apologetically to NELLY, as the RACEGOER and FRIENDS swar

dialogues.speaker: RACEGOER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (to anyone) Mr Charles Dickens, ladies and gentlemen. In Doncaster! A gathering Crowd, several RACEGOERS craning their necks see-

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: Thank you..Thank you. NELLY looks on helpless, eyes darting to MARIA and FANNY, giggling. DICKENS subsumed in handshakes and delighted RACEGOERS. NELLY, looks on. DICKENS back at NELLY, smiles apologetically. MRS TERNAN seeing this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A peeling bedroom- The BURST and LIFE of FANNY, NELLY and MARIA carrying cas newly returned home.

dialogues.speaker: FANNY
dialogues.text: Home!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Later - Suitcases are dropped, hat boxes are dumped on the bed. T slow unpacking and chaos of the nomadic life as NELLY, MA and FANNY kneel shaking out dresses and pulling out shoes clothes from the chaos. FANNY absently sings to herself, considering the sleeve of a dress, faded and frayed.

dialogues.speaker: FANNY
dialogues.text: This will not stretch to another season. I cannot mend under the sleeve again.  Blue Revisions dated 11th June 2012 40. MARIA looks up from unpacking, reaching a hand out.

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: The cuffs are still good and there is lace on the collar we can still save.

dialogues.speaker: FANNY
dialogues.text: You think? CLOSE UP on FINGERS, considering delicate lace.

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: (nods ) I‘1l unpick it. FANNY smiles, her thanks, MARIA taking the dress, FANNY resumes unpacking, her song underscores.

dialogues.speaker: NELLY
dialogues.text: Maria, also this hem..My stitching is awful. NELLY holds up her dress, MARIA takes it, smiles—

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: I will..again.

dialogues.speaker: NELLY
dialogues.text: Thank you..thank you..Thank you.. MARIA’s HAND gently brushing NELLY’s cheek. The FALL of NELLY’s hair, lost in quiet focused sorting of clothes.

dialogues.speaker: MRS TERNAN
dialogues.text: (entering) I am collecting washing. NELLY holds up some dirty garments.

dialogues.speaker: NELLY
dialogues.text: Here.. MRS TERNAN looks down, having just picked up an armful of dresses.

dialogues.speaker: MRS TERNAN
dialogues.text: (in passing) Nelly- Underneath a signed copy of David Copperfield. MRS TERNAN picks it up, opening it. MRS TERNAN (CONT’D) It is signed. NELLY hurriedly goes to take it.  28 29 30 Blue Revisions dated 11th June 2012 41.

dialogues.speaker: NELLY
dialogues.text: A souvenir.

dialogues.speaker: MRS TERNAN
dialogues.text: It is to be treasured. MRS TERNAN holds it out, FANNY looks up curious-

dialogues.speaker: FANNY
dialogues.text: Yes..Indeed. FANNY smiles, NELLY nods, taking the book,pocketing it, a little self-conscious. EXT. DRIVE. GAD’S HILL.KENT. 1857. DAWN. 28

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A handsome house. Light illuminating some windows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A darkened dressing room- The SOUND of DICKENS urinating into the pot. He then goes over to a waiting basin. DICKENS hands cupping icy water, washing his face in the bowl. He stands, drying his face, reflection caught in the mirror, restless, half dressed-

dialogues.speaker: CATHERINE OOV
dialogues.text: (calling out) Charles- On DICKENS fingers fumbling in the dark, hurriedly button up his shirt and reaching for his jacket.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CATHERINE stirring from slumber, sits up peering through gloomy morning light- CHARLES, a shadowy figures stands in the doorway of the dressing room now almost dressed-

dialogues.speaker: CATHERINE
dialogues.text: Why are you up so early?

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: I must go to London.

dialogues.speaker: CATHERINE
dialogues.text: Now? But there will be no train.

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: Then I shall walk.  31 32 Blue Revisions dated 11th June 2012 42.

dialogues.speaker: CATHERINE
dialogues.text: It will take you all day.

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: Then it will take me all day. DICKENS turns, his back to CATHERINE, resuming dressing. CATHERINE eyes pricking with tears, looks away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DICKENS walking across the field in the dawn light. The m hovering. Dew heavy on the tall grass- Eyes focused, heart fixed towards London. Gads Hill left far behind. INT. AUDITORIUM. HAYMARKET THEATRE. LONDON. 1857. NIGHT.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Darkness- SIR PETER. What! You rogue! Don't you ask the girl's consent first? DICKENS face illuminated by stage light, dark eyes lost i quiet yet animated watching, captivated by NELLY on stage playing the part of Maria in School for Scandal- NELLY/MARIA. For Shame, Charles, I protest Sir Peter, there has not been a word.

dialogues.speaker: HECKLER
dialogues.text: (shouting out) BECAUSE WE CAN’T HEAR A WORD!

dialogues.speaker: LAUGHTER-
dialogues.text: DICKENS turns, furious. SIR OLIVER. Well then the fewer the better, may your love for each other never know abatement.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: NELLY on stage, ill at ease, but DICKENS is enraptured, oblivious, to the general GROANS and FIDGETING amongst th audience.  33 Blue Revisions dated 11th June 2012 43.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLES
dialogues.text: No sanctuary near but love and you. You can indeed each anxious fear remove, for even Scandal dies if you approve. AUDIENCE MEMBERS peer forward, whispering, on recognising DICKENS, yet DICKENS watches on, eyes only for NELLY, on stage.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: The final moments of the play, NELLY/MARIA, face rouged, caught mid scene, the black of the auditorium ahead of he

dialogues.speaker: CHARLES, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: "Bless'd were the fair like you; her faults who stopp'd, and closed her follies when the curtain dropp'd! The HANDSOME LOVER turns to NELLY/ MARIA, carefully cuppi her hand.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLES, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: No more in vice or error to engage, Or play the fool at large on life's great stage." On DICKENS, listening intently- The curtain falls.

dialogues.speaker: BRAVO
dialogues.text: DICKENS, clutches the seating rail, in standing ovation.

dialogues.speaker: BRAVO
dialogues.text: The CURTAIN RISES- NELLY’s eyes silently searching, flushing on seeing, DICK lost in watching her. INT. DRESSING ROOM/CORRIDOR. BACKSTAGE. THEATRE. LONDON. 1857. NIGHT.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DICKENS squeezed into NELLY’s tiny dressing room, raising toast to NELLY, surrounded by MRS TERNAN, FANNY, MARIA, a

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: One of the finest performances I have ever seen. Sheridan would be dancing in his grave.  Blue Revisions dated 11th June 2012 44. Cheers. Laughter. The EBB and FLOW of WELL-WISHERS and AC celebrating, DICKENS pressed against the wall, as he smil to let a PRETTY ACTRESS pass, a bouquet of flowers in han brushing his face.

dialogues.speaker: MRS TERNAN
dialogues.text: You were very good, Nelly, dearest. MRS TERNAN, kisses her. FANNY close by.

dialogues.speaker: NELLY
dialogues.text: Really?

dialogues.speaker: FANNY
dialogues.text: There is such clarity in your performance, Nelly. NELLY sinks a little, FANNY squeezes her hand, relenting.

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: You looked so beautiful. NELLY squeezes MARIA, spying DICKENS, the sense of improm party all around, strung between dressing room and corrid

dialogues.speaker: MRS TERNAN
dialogues.text: Mr Dickens, why did you not warn us you were coming?

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: A last minute impulse.

dialogues.speaker: BUCKSTONE
dialogues.text: Mr Dickens- MRS TERNAN goes off, lost in conversation with the manage BUCKSTONE, he shakes DICKENS hand with a flourish in pass

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: My dear Buckstone-

dialogues.speaker: MR BUCKSTONE
dialogues.text: Always a pleasure to have you grace our theatre.

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: Thank you..Thank you..A wonderful night. The HANDSOME ACTOR passes-—

dialogues.speaker: HANDSOME ACTOR
dialogues.text: Miss Ellen, you were marvellous. NELLY smiles, face aglow, squeezing the HANDSOME ACTOR’s hand. DICKENS seeing this.  Blue Revisions dated 11th June 2012 45.

dialogues.speaker: NELLY
dialogues.text: Thank you, Mr Arnott. DICKENS oddly nervous, smiles, hovering between staying a going, unsettling NELLY, the HANDSOME ACTOR moves away. A around the party in full swing, NELLY and DICKENS stand c by, wedged between dressing room door and corridor-

dialogues.speaker: MRS TERNAN
dialogues.text: And how is your writing Mr Dickens?

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: Ferocious. Up at seven; a cold bath before breakfast, and blaze away, until three o’clock. I fight not to be distracted. DICKENS suddenly loses himself watching NELLY in conversa with the HANDSOME YOUNG ACTOR. She turns, seeing DICKENS-

dialogues.speaker: NELLY
dialogues.text: Won't you sit? NELLY gestures to a chair close by-

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: No..I don’t think.. NELLY’s face falls, hurrying to shroud her disappointment

dialogues.speaker: NELLY
dialogues.text: Of course...Yes..Yes..It is very late I am sure you must be tired.

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: So much to do I don’t know whether my head is on or off- DICKENS flushed blusters, watching as NELLY is effortless drawn away by the HANDSOME ACTOR along a corridor to a cluster of WAITING FRIENDS-

dialogues.speaker: HANDSOME ACTOR
dialogues.text: Nelly, you must meet my very good friends...

dialogues.speaker: NELLY
dialogues.text: Yes..Yes..I would be delighted to meet them. DICKENS sips his drink, desperately trying not to follow NELLY as she smiles and laughs. MRS TERNAN hovers, eyes holding DICKENS’-

dialogues.speaker: MRS TERNAN
dialogues.text: She is much in demand.  34 Blue Revisions dated 11th June 2012 46.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The STILL of a pretty if peeling sitting room- SUDDENLY the SOUND of a door opening, LAUGHTER-

dialogues.speaker: MRS TERNAN OOV
dialogues.text: Come through..come through- A lamp is lit, casting its warm glow across the frivolous makeshift sitting room, adorned with the artefacts of pas performances, pieces of stage set, clearly now in use as furniture. MRS TERNAN smiles, greeting DICKENS caught in flurry of FANNY, MARIA and NELLY as they unpeel coats and discard hats and rogue door hooks.

dialogues.speaker: MRS TERNAN
dialogues.text: Fanny, Maria, we must feed our guest. There is some cold meat in the larder. And a little bread and fruit.

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: Please.. Please do not trouble yourself.

dialogues.speaker: MRS TERNAN
dialogues.text: Nelly, a drink for Mr Dickens. NELLY hurries off in search of wine and food. MRS TERNAN (CONT’D) Sit here. It is the only seat in the house that does not sag if you shift in search of comfort. NELLY, flushes, thrusting a glass of wine in DICKENS’ han aware of his gaze travelling over the garish and rather threadbare fixtures and fittings-

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: Thank you. This is warm and charming-

dialogues.speaker: NELLY
dialogues.text: Do not lean too far back, Mr Dickens. DICKENS lurches back, clutching the arm of the chair.

dialogues.speaker: NELLY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: The arm has a habit of coming unattached.

dialogues.speaker: LAUGHTER-
dialogues.text: 35 Blue Revisions dated 11th June 2012 47.

dialogues.speaker: FANNY
dialogues.text: (entering) Ham and plums and some biscuits.

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: And cheese..We have cheese. MARIA smiles with delight, placing the cheese next to FAN board of food on the side.

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: Then I will never leave.

dialogues.speaker: LAUGHTER-
dialogues.text: DICKENS smiles, eyes holding on NELLY’s as they fall on t food.

dialogues.speaker: LATER-
dialogues.text: DICKENS, talking to a tired and lazy audience, on the edg sleep-

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: And then what did you say?

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: What I should have said was “Mr Anderson though your Ugly Duckling has delighted, you have slept in this room for five weeks now. You must go home. ”

dialogues.speaker: FANNY
dialogues.text: But you did not?

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: I did not.

dialogues.speaker: NELLY
dialogues.text: Why didn’t you?

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: It would have broken his heart. So instead I inscribed a volume of my latest work From his friend and admirer Charles Dickens. Though I should have added..May you never outstay your welcome so long again.”

dialogues.speaker: LAUGHTER-
dialogues.text: DICKENS looks across at MARIA stifling a yawn. NELLY and FANNY following his gaze, lost in listening to him.  36 Blue Revisions dated 11th June 2012 48.

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: And now it seems I have done the same. MARIA stirs.

dialogues.speaker: ALL
dialogues.text: No..No.. They all make to stand-

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: I will thank you, ladies, for such a pleasurable night. Life is nothing without good company. NELLY smiles, DICKENS smiles-

dialogues.speaker: MRS TERNAN
dialogues.text: Let me show you out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The soft glow of the lamp illuminating MRS TERNAN and DIC as she helps him on with his coat.

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: It is a very pretty cottage.

dialogues.speaker: MRS TERNAN
dialogues.text: If lacking in space. MRS TERNAN hands DICKENS her coat. MRS TERNAN (CONT’D) The rewards of our profession are rarely monetary. But I would have it no other way.

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: No one is useless in this world if they may lighten the burden. If I may be of assistance... MRS TERNAN holds DICKENS look with direct gaze.

dialogues.speaker: MRS TERNAN
dialogues.text: (hushed) My daughters are fine young women but I am anxious sometimes for their future. (beat) I cannot risk Nelly’s reputation. DICKEN hesitates, MRS TERNAN unwavering.  37 Blue Revisions dated 11th June 2012 49.

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: I hope nothing I could offer would compromise her. MRS TERNAN hesitates, looking up, just seeing NELLY, stan in the doorway.

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: So, good night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A dimly lit street- A YOUNG BOY pulling a cart, wheels turning on the cobbles DICKENS sidestepping him, quickening his pace, passing th shadowy figures of LATE NIGHT REVELLERS, sensing footstep behind him-

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG PROSTITUTE
dialogues.text: Shilling a blow, Sir. DICKENS hesitates, turns, a YOUNG PROSTITUTE[12 yrs] loitering in the shadows-

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: I will give you five- DICKENS fishes a shilling out of his coin-

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: .--if you go home safely tonight. The YOUNG PROSTITUTE hesitates, reaching out, taking the coins from him.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG PROSTITUTE
dialogues.text: I can play house, Sir. Want me as your wife, sir? DICKENS hesitates, one hand reaching out, touching her fa seeing she is no older than twelve.

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: Where is your mother? The YOUNG PROSTITUTE laughs, ducking away. On DICKENS watching, distraught and troubled, the bob of dark curls disappearing down a dimly lit street. DICKENS turns walks away, turning into-  38 39 Blue Revisions dated 11th June 2012 50.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DICKENS POV as he walks. He sees the faces of GRUBBY STRE CHILDREN and YOUNG PROSTITUTES face after face, caught in labyrinth of alleyways.

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS VO
dialogues.text: Last Saturday I sat next toa gentleman at dinner and he asked me in some fury why it was that our city should help those who do not help themselves. DICKENS keeps walking passing an almost hellish world of poverty and sickness, BABIES crying in YOUNG MOTHERS arms

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS VO, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: By ‘those’ he meant the many fallen women that we see around us every day and their offspring, many who rely on this hospital today. I replied. SCAB RIDDEN INFANTS staring blankly out of rundown doorwa

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS VO, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: The two grim nurses, poverty and sickness bring these children before you and preside over their births, rock their wretched cradles, nail down their little coffins, pile up the earth above their graves. Their unnatural deaths form one third of the annual deaths in this great town. “But what of God?” He piously replied. “What of him?” I asked.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An ATTENTIVE AUDIENCE of WEALTHY BUSINESSMEN and WIVES, BENEFACTORS, INTELLECTUALS and PATRONS. Above reads a banner- Prosperity to the Hospital for Sick Children- DICKENS caught amidst the marble busts of prominent statesmen.

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: “I feel sure God looks leniently on all vice that proceeds from human tenderness and natural passion."  40 Blue Revisions dated 11th June 2012 51. CLOSE ON NELLY shining with pride. Some way to the back M TERNAN, FANNY and MARIA looking on. JOHN stands a few inc behind, looking on.

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I hope we will too and give generously tonight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: NELLY, MRS TERNAN, MARIA and FANNY standing standing behi table on which are silver collecting plates and a collect box.

dialogues.speaker: NELLY
dialogues.text: Good night, Sir..Thank you. They smiles at the SPILL of PEOPLE putting change and not into the plates.

dialogues.speaker: MRS TERNAN
dialogues.text: Surely you can do better than that, Sir?

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: Five pounds, Nelly. Five pounds. DICKENS crossing the room-

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: Goodnight. .Goodnight..Thank you. DIGNITARIES and GUESTS draining from the room, heading home.

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Maria have you fleeced them? DICKENS moving over to greet NELLY, MRS TERNAN, MARIA and FANNY lining up the donation boxes.

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: With every ounce of my soul, Mr Dickens.

dialogues.speaker: FANNY
dialogues.text: We can barely carry them. DICKENS nods, oddly dishevelled, distracted tonight. He smiles at them all-  4l Blue Revisions dated 11th June 2012 52.

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: Thank you. Thank You..Goodness..I did not believe we would raise so much money...Where does one begin? DICKENS fingers lightly grazing the boxes, heavy with money, lined up on a table.

dialogues.speaker: NELLY
dialogues.text: They will take some counting. He looks at NELLY, her smile quietly disarming him.

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: Yes..Yes.

dialogues.speaker: MRS TERNAN
dialogues.text: Such an achievement.

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: We must celebrate.

dialogues.speaker: NELLY
dialogues.text: Yes..Yes..We must.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A wide, drawing room, some furniture covered in dust shee DICKENS tentatively leading MRS TERNAN through the ghostl darkened landscape of Tavistock House.

dialogues.speaker: MRS TERNAN
dialogues.text: You are moving in or out Mr Dickens? A dust sheet covering a grand piano and the occasional chair just visible in another room.

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: I am thinking of letting it. FANNY, NELLY and MARIA close behind, the collecting boxes being carried by DICKENS valet, JOHN, lugging boxes that puts on the floor.

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: My wife prefers to live outside of the public glare. London tires her and Gad’s Hill is where she likes to retreat with the children. NELLY takes in the silence, the endless emptiness, eviden in every room.  Blue Revisions dated 11th June 2012 53.

dialogues.speaker: MRS TERNAN
dialogues.text: Gad’s Hill. Is that in Rochester-

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: (nods ) It is close. Walking distance.

dialogues.speaker: MRS TERNAN
dialogues.text: Nelly was born in Rochester. DICKENS laughs, delighted at the coincidence, looking to NELLY.

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: I was schooled in Chatham.

dialogues.speaker: NELLY
dialogues.text: Yes but my earliest memories are of Newcastle.

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: Newcastle I do not know so well. FANNY and MARIA taking in the room. FANNY turns, seeing DICKENS smiling at NELLY. MRS TERNAN peers through the window, out into the murky darkness-

dialogues.speaker: MRS TERNAN
dialogues.text: Ah a garden. A grand piano, covered in a dust sheet, NELLY pulls a cor aside to reveal dusty keys. LIPS CLOSE to an ivory key, s blows-—

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: (leading her) Would you like to see it? MRS TERNAN laughs, DICKENS leading her out.

dialogues.speaker: MRS TERNAN
dialogues.text: (following him) It is getting dark.

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: Come..Come. Let me show you. DICKENS leads MRS TERNAN out, leaving FANNY, MARIA and NE

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: He always seems so alone.

dialogues.speaker: FANNY
dialogues.text: Yes.  42 Blue Revisions dated 11th June 2012 54. NELLY presses down on a piano key, testing the note, caug on a repetitive middle c-

dialogues.speaker: FANNY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (hushed) It is like a mausoleum. On NELLY watching DICKENS leading MRS TERNAN around a darkened garden.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: NELLY caught peering at DICKENS desk; meticulously laid out papers, manuscripts and pencils, sharpened and in a row.

dialogues.speaker: MRS TERNAN OOV
