dialogues.text: (calling back) Nelly- MRS TERNAN, MARIA and FANNY preparing to leave, standing in a distant hallway. DICKENS hovers, considering the many boxes now lined up on the floor.

dialogues.speaker: MRS TERNAN
dialogues.text: We must leave you. Fanny has an audition in the morning and must rest her voice.

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: Yes of course yes.

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: We have a wager on how much was collected. I think five hundred but Fanny thinks-

dialogues.speaker: FANNY
dialogues.text: More..More.. DICKENS smiles, making his goodbyes as they reach for gloves and coats, pulling them on as they head towards the door.

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: I will count them right away. They must be banked tomorrow.

dialogues.speaker: MRS TERNAN
dialogues.text: You will be up all night.

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: I don’t sleep well anyway.  43 Blue Revisions dated 11th June 2012 55.

dialogues.speaker: NELLY
dialogues.text: We could help you. Together it will take us no time.

dialogues.speaker: FANNY
dialogues.text: You have rehearsal in the morning, Nelly.

dialogues.speaker: MRS TERNAN
dialogues.text: Nelly and I will stay and help Mr Dickens. If he does not object.

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: Well..No..I..thank you.

dialogues.speaker: FANNY
dialogues.text: Mama- MRS TERNAN offers firm gaze, ushering FANNY and MARIA out

dialogues.speaker: MRS TERNAN
dialogues.text: We shall not be late. FANNY disappearing out into the dark night looks back at NELLY, smiling reassuringly.

dialogues.speaker: MARIA/ FANNY
dialogues.text: Good night.

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: Good night. The door closes-

dialogues.speaker: SILENCE-
dialogues.text: DICKENS stands awkward, hovering, unsure what comes next.

dialogues.speaker: NELLY
dialogues.text: Where shall we count them?

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: Yes..Yes..Through here (gesturing) Yes, through here. NELLY turns looking to MRS TERNAN but she ignores NELLY, following DICKENS through.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A snaking line of coins piled into small pillars on a table-  Blue Revisions dated 11th June 2012 56. NELLY and DICKENS lost in counting facing one another. Th whisper to one another, MRS TERNAN snoozes in a chair clo by-

dialogues.speaker: NELLY
dialogues.text: Fourteen hundred and ninety eight,fourteen hundred and ninety nine..two shillings and tuppence. NELLY finishes counting triumphant.

dialogues.speaker: NELLY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Nearly one thousand five hundred pounds.

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: No?..Really.. They laugh. Triumphant.

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: We are rich...

dialogues.speaker: NELLY
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: They will be delighted...Until the next time. DICKENS scoops up the money, easing it back into the boxes in piles.

dialogues.speaker: NELLY
dialogues.text: (sudden) Do you like this life?

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: Well - it is not always of my own making but- NELLY waits. DICKENS silent, cutting himself off.

dialogues.speaker: NELLY
dialogues.text: I don’t think I would. Being so constantly on show, so constantly watched.

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: I have my work. It is a great foil. They try but they cannot always find you there.

dialogues.speaker: NELLY
dialogues.text: They?  44 Blue Revisions dated 11th June 2012 57.

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: The hawkers. The men who need to make money. Who look to trip you up. And then there are the admirers. Those who wish you to be more than you can possibly be.

dialogues.speaker: NELLY
dialogues.text: And what is that?

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: Good...I suppose. DICKENS smiles, caught out, looking away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Later - on MRS TERNAN still asleep. Flickering candlelight- NELLY and DICKENS sharing a picnic supper perched at a cooks table. A half open bottle of wine, the remains of a make shift supper. CLOSE on DICKENS-

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: My father was sent toa debtor’s prison when I was twelve. I worked in a blacking factory thereafter, sealing bottles,sticking labels. (beat) It was hateful.

dialogues.speaker: NELLY
dialogues.text: You were fond of your father?

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: He was my first audience. I honed my comic lines on him. DICKENS spoons the last mouthful of eggs, caught out.

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You are too good at this. I have told you too much. You, now. You.

dialogues.speaker: NELLY
dialogues.text: No really..There is little to tell.. (conceding) My father - An actor. Son of a Dublin grocer. Also in debt. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Blue Revisions dated 11th June 2012 58.

dialogues.speaker: NELLY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Also dead. When I was seven. In an asylum. Mother never talks about it. I had a brother. He died at 10 months. Though how a boy would have fit with three girls. We are as thick as thieves. NELLY looks to MRS TERNAN.

dialogues.speaker: NELLY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: She is devoted to us. Our life is unpredictable. NELLY aware of DICKENS concentration on her.

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: You are- DICKENS laughs, relishing NELLY.

dialogues.speaker: NELLY
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: You are so free.

dialogues.speaker: NELLY
dialogues.text: And you are not.

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: I dream sometimes that there is a place where no-one knows who I am, or asks me what I think, or even cares for my opinion. Somewhere..where I can just...live...heart beating...chest rising..Just breathe. DICKENS flushes, deflects, topping up his glass. The mood suddenly sombre-

dialogues.speaker: NELLY
dialogues.text: It is late. She will sleep all night if we leave her. NELLY peers through MRS TERNAN still asleep in a chair.

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: Of course. I will ask John to bring the carriage round- DICKENS makes to go, suddenly something makes him stop.  45 Blue Revisions dated 11th June 2012 59.

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Tell me a secret.

dialogues.speaker: NELLY
dialogues.text: What kind of secret?

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: Anything..Something.. Something you have never told anyone or perhaps never thought of telling.

dialogues.speaker: NELLY
dialogues.text: (beat) My middle name is ‘Lawless’. (beat) Now your turn. What is your secret?

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: Ellen Lawless Ternan. That is my secret. They hold each others gaze. SUDDENLY beyond MRS TERNAN st the moment broken, her eyes opening.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: NELLY, stiff in bonnet and corset, walking across the san BENHAM by her side. They have been walking in silence for some time. The grey wash of sea beyond, lapping at their boots as they walk, faces flushed, pressed to the wind.

dialogues.speaker: NELLY
dialogues.text: I like to search for faces amongst the patterns in the sand.

dialogues.speaker: BENHAM
dialogues.text: And do you find them?

dialogues.speaker: NELLY
dialogues.text: Sometimes. Mostly monsters and angels. BENHAM smiles, NELLY smiles. The DRAG of a FISHING BOAT crossing their paths. They navigate their way past the FISHERMAN pulling the boat across the sand.

dialogues.speaker: BENHAM
dialogues.text: So I thought Great Expectations might be a choice for our readings. David Copperfield is of course a contender but Great Expectations wins out for me in the end.

dialogues.speaker: NELLY
dialogues.text: Very good.  Blue Revisions dated 11th June 2012 60.

dialogues.speaker: BENHAM
dialogues.text: Do you agree?

dialogues.speaker: NELLY
dialogues.text: It is a fine novel. OTHER FISHERMAN and a FISHERWOMAN sit knotting nets. They walk on, BENHAM silent, her steady, calm companion, yet noting her distraction.

dialogues.speaker: BENHAM
dialogues.text: Mrs Wharton Robinson... Forgive me if I am intruding but...I see you are so often...distracted..There is some..As if a part of you is... absent. I do not wish to intrude. You talk I am sure to your husband-

dialogues.speaker: NELLY
dialogues.text: No- A COUPLE pass, part of the ebb and flow of life, walking another direction, NELLY nods, in brief greeting, waverin momentarily, waiting for them to pass.

dialogues.speaker: BENHAM
dialogues.text: Not all wives do..To confide in the person you love the most..Sometimes that is hard.

dialogues.speaker: NELLY
dialogues.text: George is a good man. A very good man.

dialogues.speaker: BENHAM
dialogues.text: Of course. NELLY lost deep within herself.

dialogues.speaker: BENHAM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: But you are troubled.

dialogues.speaker: BENHAM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: It comes and then it goes but it returns. I wish to help you...I hope I can be someone you can trust.

dialogues.speaker: NELLY
dialogues.text: Really. I am quite well.

dialogues.speaker: BENHAM
dialogues.text: You are not.  46 47 Blue Revisions dated 11th June 2012 61.

dialogues.speaker: NELLY
dialogues.text: Please, Mr Benham...

dialogues.speaker: BENHAM
dialogues.text: I will listen without judgement. NELLY turns, looks at BENHAM, the grey scene beyond.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dawn- NELLY waking listening to distant, muffled conversation. Reaching for her nightgown, NELLY pulls it across her shoulders, slipping out of bed. MARIA, sleeping by her si barely stirs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: NELLY’s bare feet walking down the stairs. Beyond the doo ajar, MRS TERNAN and FANNY in another room, locked in hea debate.

dialogues.speaker: FANNY
dialogues.text: She is barely 18.

dialogues.speaker: MRS TERNAN
dialogues.text: I have never had to concern myself with regard to you or Maria. There is always another tour for you and your younger sister..Mr. Buckstone has already enquired if Maria might be free for Pantomime. But Nelly...Nelly is different. I love her. I love her dearly but - her talent lies elsewhere. Charles Dickens is not merely some opportunist, some adventurer. I am thinking of what life will offer her. I am thinking of her future.

dialogues.speaker: FANNY
dialogues.text: But what future would that be, mother?

dialogues.speaker: MRS TERNAN
dialogues.text: Our profession is hard enough. You do not give it up. It gives you up. MRS TERNAN suddenly stops mid sentence, seeing NELLY, standing in the doorway, hearing all.  48 49 50 Blue Revisions dated 11th June 2012 62.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: NELLY sits on the toilet, head sunk in her hand. Blotting tears with a piece of ripped up news paper- Footsteps- NELLY furiously scrunches up the paper, wiping away her tears, ignoring the tap at the door.

dialogues.speaker: NELLY
dialogues.text: Go away Fanny.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FANNY sinks down on a flower pot, outside the toilet door

dialogues.speaker: FANNY
dialogues.text: I will stay here all day if I have to. (beat) Nelly-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: NELLY, devastated-

dialogues.speaker: NELLY
dialogues.text: I am a terrible actress. It is true. Please do not lie. NELLY stands, her forehead against the cool of the door.

dialogues.speaker: FANNY OOV
dialogues.text: Nelly, you are the truest person I know in life. But you are not an actress. NELLY closes her eyes stung, but oddly resigned.

dialogues.speaker: NELLY
dialogues.text: Did no one think of telling me?

dialogues.speaker: FANNY OOV
dialogues.text: Nelly-

dialogues.speaker: NELLY
dialogues.text: You have clearly discussed it. What other arrangements have been made which I do not know about?

dialogues.speaker: FANNY OOV
dialogues.text: It is only because we care so.  51 52 Blue Revisions dated 11th June 2012 63.

dialogues.speaker: NELLY
dialogues.text: I will not be bought or sold, Fanny. Whatever it is...it is not that. NELLY fights back the last furious tears-

dialogues.speaker: FANNY OOV
dialogues.text: Do you love him? NELLY’s eyes open, her face betraying all-

dialogues.speaker: NELLY
dialogues.text: He is married-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FANNY, hands pressed to the door, hesitating-

dialogues.speaker: FANNY
dialogues.text: That has not stopped him falling in love with you.

dialogues.speaker: SILENCE UNTIL-
dialogues.text: The door slowly opens, NELLY, face stained with tears, pe around. FANNY smiles, rubbing a blot of ink on NELLY’s no with her thumb.

dialogues.speaker: FANNY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (eyeing inky nose) You have the prime minster all over your nose. CLOSE UP ON NELLY, the pain of hearing this truth, yet smiling with affection for her FANNY-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE UP ON NELLY the same look of pain- with BENHAM once more on the beach, looking out at a YOUNG MAN and his SON flying a kite far off-

dialogues.speaker: NELLY
dialogues.text: I was an actress.

dialogues.speaker: BENHAM
dialogues.text: An actress.

dialogues.speaker: NELLY
dialogues.text: Not a very good one. (beat) My husband has indulged my interest in the theatre but he is ignorant of my past.  53 Blue Revisions dated 11th June 2012 64. NELLY looks to BENHAM, hovering on telling him.

dialogues.speaker: NELLY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: It is hard to reconcile this with life as the wife of a headmaster. So I have hidden it. A BOY far off with his FATHER in the rock pools.

dialogues.speaker: NELLY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I was not a child when I met Mr Dickens. I was eighteen. George believes I am considerably younger than I am. BENHAM stares, with sudden comprehension.NELLY stops. The cliffs fierce and towering behind them. The ocean in fron

dialogues.speaker: NELLY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: He knows nothing of the depth of my affection.. (beat) My former affection for Mr Dickens.

dialogues.speaker: BENHAM
dialogues.text: I see. BENHAM hesitates, a seeping realisation evident in his ey

dialogues.speaker: BENHAM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You will never tell your husband. She looks out at the grey churning sea.

dialogues.speaker: NELLY
dialogues.text: He must never know. Never. BENHAM, listening intently, yet giving nothing away. She turns, looks at him.

dialogues.speaker: NELLY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Mr Benham, I have such remorse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Spring- NELLY, eyes closed, surrounded by flowers, a birthday cake held in front of her-

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: Open your eyes. MARIA, FANNY, MRS TERNAN, the FLIGHTY ACTRESS and OTHERS Cheers as NELLY blows out the candles. A beautiful house just visible beyond-  54 Blue Revisions dated 11th June 2012 65.

dialogues.speaker: MRS TERNAN
dialogues.text: Happy Birthday, darling.

dialogues.speaker: ALL
dialogues.text: Happy birthday..Happy Birthday.

dialogues.speaker: NELLY
dialogues.text: Maria, is it raisin? MARIA smiles, NELLY smothers her in kisses, excited and excitable, twirling across the grass. A distant rap at the door- NELLY absorbed, opening presents. A few moments later a MAID appears.

dialogues.speaker: MAID
dialogues.text: (to NELLY) Miss Ellen, Mrs Dickens to see you. NELLY’s face falls, the noise of the party hushes to a still- FANNY and MARIA look to one another. MRS TERNAN goes to greet her, NELLY gently stops her. NELLY heads inside leaving behind the chaotic party, lazy on the grass-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CATHERINE DICKENS standing in the parlour, oddly fragile, rouge dotting her pale cheeks. She turns on seeing NELLY standing in the doorway.

dialogues.speaker: CATHERINE
dialogues.text: I thought this was the right house... NELLY enters, plumping a cushion on a seat, and offering it in gesture.

dialogues.speaker: NELLY
dialogues.text: Please. Won’t you sit down? CATHERINE, eyes silently tracing over the pretty sitting room, eyes alighting on a series of tiny prints of costumes hung on the wall.

dialogues.speaker: CATHERINE
dialogues.text: I had heard he had found you somewhere close on the square- CATHERINE peers closer.  Blue Revisions dated 11th June 2012 66. CATHERINE (CONT’D) (peering closer) Such attention to detail. NELLY follows CATHERINE’s gaze-

dialogues.speaker: NELLY
dialogues.text: It is all just paste and glass. Outside, distant whoops and laughter-

dialogues.speaker: NELLY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You find us in disarray. NELLY nods towards half packed cases.

dialogues.speaker: NELLY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: My mother and sister Frances are to go to Italy. My sister is to be a governess to the Trollope family.

dialogues.speaker: CATHERINE
dialogues.text: Really?

dialogues.speaker: NELLY
dialogues.text: Mr Dickens has kindly made the introduction. He has been more than charitable to my family. CATHERINE nods, considering NELLY, with cool resignation.

dialogues.speaker: CATHERINE
dialogues.text: My husband has always been very generous. CATHERINE holds out a small velvet box to NELLY- CATHERINE (CONT’D) Happy Birthday Miss Ternan. NELLY takes it, with surprise, flushing. A game of musical chairs or the like just visible playing out in the garden- CATHERINE (CONT’D) Won't you open it? NELLY hesitates, looking down at the box in her hand, tentatively fingering the paper. CATHERINE (CONT’D) It is a gift from Charles. It was mistakenly delivered to me.  Blue Revisions dated 11th June 2012 67. NELLY, inwardly reeling, carefully unpeels the paper, tearing it a little- CATHERINE (CONT’D) The jewellers naturally believing- Opening it, her breath catches on seeing- A beautiful bracelet, embedded with deep red Rubies- CATHERINE (CONT’D) Charles was eager that I ensure it found its way to its rightful recipient. NELLY, catches on this, embarrassed by such obvious cruelty from DICKENS- CATHERINE (CONT’D) He is fond of you. NELLY flushes-— CATHERINE (CONT’D) And you of him? NELLY hesitates- CATHERINE (CONT’D) That is a silly question. He is Mr Charles Dickens. .Even in those early years together even I could not fail to be impressed. But you will find, you must share him with his public. They will be the constant and in truth you will never absolutely know which one he loves the most. You or them. I do not believe he knows himself. But they will not give him up, of that you can be sure, Miss Ternan. They will love him beyond the grave. (close to) Will you love him as long? (beat) I am interrupting your party. CATHERINE, making to stand, nods, holding NELLY with quiet passive scrutiny.  Blue Revisions dated 11th June 2012 68. CATHERINE (CONT’D) Charley said you were not that pretty. I could not remember but I see now my son was being kind to me.

dialogues.speaker: NELLY
dialogues.text: I am really far too old for parties. There is not a soul under twenty in attendance.

dialogues.speaker: CATHERINE
dialogues.text: Well Charles should be here soon and he is nothing if not youthful. CATHERINE makes to go-

dialogues.speaker: CATHERINE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I wish you a very happy birthday. Far off the party in full swing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The aftermath of the party, drained of GUESTS, the TERNAN family seated, sober after CATHERINE’s visit- NELLY, the ruby bracelet resting between her fingers,MARI and FANNY seated close by, unsettled. MARIA sketches, let the pencil suddenly still in her hand.- SUDDENLY COLLINS and DICKENS spill through the back gate moving into the house. DICKENS tracing his fingers along papered wall, peering at it with delight.

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: New paper on the wall?

dialogues.speaker: MRS TERNAN
dialogues.text: Yes. Do you like it?

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: Very much..very much..You have made it home.

dialogues.speaker: MRS TERNAN
dialogues.text: We have tried. It is a most beautiful house.

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: Isn’t it?

dialogues.speaker: MRS TERNAN
dialogues.text: Thank you.  Blue Revisions dated 11th June 2012 68A. DICKENS beams, COLLINS by his side, sensing all is not qu right.

dialogues.speaker: COLLINS
dialogues.text: And the chairs? New?

dialogues.speaker: MRS TERNAN
dialogues.text: Yes-?

dialogues.speaker: COLLINS
dialogues.text: We are too late? Are we too late? NELLY snaps the box shut, hurrying to pocket it.

dialogues.speaker: MRS TERNAN
dialogues.text: You have missed the cake. COLLINS snatches the last piece of cake off a table, positioned under a tree.

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: No, say it is not so. Have we missed all the fun? DICKENS standing with COLLINS both dressed in party hats and beaming, a tension puncturing their fun.

dialogues.speaker: MRS TERNAN
dialogues.text: We had hoped you would provide it.  56 57 58 Blue Revisions dated 11th June 2012 69.

dialogues.speaker: COLLINS
dialogues.text: There is only one thing for it. We will have to whisk her away. NELLY scoops up a stray ribbon, wrapping it around her finger, busying herself as she walks back to the house, passing DICKENS. He gently stops her, a hand on her arm, quizzical as she refuses to meet his gaze.

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: Say you will come? On NELLY, caught in the conflict of feelings. MRS TERNAN, MARIA and FANNY looking on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: NELLY squeezed between DICKENS and COLLINS, being quietly led-

dialogues.speaker: NELLY
dialogues.text: Where are we going? DICKENS smiles, heady and happy, NELLY concedes, a growing fury bubbling underneath.

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: You shall see.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: COLLINS pulling off his coat, NELLY and DICKENS close behind, showing them in-

dialogues.speaker: COLLINS
dialogues.text: Come through..Come through. NELLY looks to DICKENS confused. A pair of ladies shoes- A ladies coat- Several hats resting on a hat stand. NELLY’s eyes grazing over them with bemused curiosity-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A pretty drawing room- CAROLINE GRAVES [late 20's] handsome and flushed, yet in delicate informal negligee, already coming through, greeting DICKENS warmly-  Blue Revisions dated 11th June 2012 70.

dialogues.speaker: CAROLINE GRAVES
dialogues.text: Wilkie, why did you not say? COLLINS kisses CAROLINE, brief yet betraying an intimacy, that unsettles NELLY.

dialogues.speaker: COLLINS
dialogues.text: We are celebrating a very special birthday.

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: Caroline may I present Miss Ellen Ternan.

dialogues.speaker: COLLINS
dialogues.text: It is her birthday today! CAROLINE greets NELLY warmly, hands cupping hers in greeting-

dialogues.speaker: CAROLINE GRAVES
dialogues.text: Happy Birthday. I have heard only good things. NELLY looks to DICKENS, not quite comprehending. DICKENS quickly looks away, deflects, peering at a picture on the wall.

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: Caroline a new painting? Quite slap up. Is the Butler about-?

dialogues.speaker: COLLINS
dialogues.text: Yes..Yes..She is about..Here she is.. (moving off) I shall find wine! HARRIET GRAVES, CAROLINE’s daughter [5 yrs] comes rushing in, in night gown-

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: My but she squeals-— DICKENS scoops HARRIET up, swinging her in his arms-

dialogues.speaker: CAROLINE GRAVES
dialogues.text: May I take your wrap and gloves?

dialogues.speaker: NELLY
dialogues.text: Thank you. But I prefer to keep them on. CAROLINE, swallows silent affront, gesturing for NELLY to sit-  59 Blue Revisions dated 11th June 2012 71.

dialogues.speaker: NELLY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What a lovely home.

dialogues.speaker: CAROLINE GRAVES
dialogues.text: Yes..Yes..Wilkie found it.. INT. DRAWING ROOM. COLLINS’ HOUSE. LONDON. 1858. NIGHT. 5 Distant laughter and screams-— CAROLINE and NELLY sit alone, in awkward silence. CHARLES, COLLINS and HARRIET lost somewhere deep within the house.

dialogues.speaker: CAROLINE GRAVES
dialogues.text: Charles christened her ‘the butler’ on their first meeting. Distant squeals, DICKENS just audible, lost in raucous game.

dialogues.speaker: NELLY
dialogues.text: It is all a game with him. (beat) She is very dear. NELLY looks away, quietly wanting to put distance between her and CAROLINE.

dialogues.speaker: CAROLINE GRAVES
dialogues.text: Does this offend you Miss Ternan? (silence) Wilkie despises marriage and as a widow it suits me well. We live very happily. (silence) But you do disapprove I see. We have fallen in love with men of standing, Miss Ternan-

dialogues.speaker: NELLY
dialogues.text: I am not in love. Squeals of delight- HARRIET rushing in DICKENS fast on her tail, collapsing into a heap on a faded chaise-

dialogues.speaker: NELLY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (sudden) It is late. Really...It is too too late. I must leave. Please excuse me Miss Graves. DICKENS sobering, hearing the urgency in NELLY’s voice-  60 Blue Revisions dated 11th June 2012 72.

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: Nelly-? INT. CARRIAGE. NEAR AMPTHILL SQUARE. LONDON.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: NELLY silent, DICKENS close by her side-

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: And still she is silent- NELLY reaches out to open the carriage door, drawing to a still. DICKENS reaches out for NELLY, stiffening on his touch-

dialogues.speaker: NELLY
dialogues.text: Mr Buckstone has offered me The World and The Stage. It has a ridiculous plot. A titled lady saved from debt by her sister, an actress.

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: But a very amusing final scene.

dialogues.speaker: NELLY
dialogues.text: It was you that secured me the role. DICKENS hesitates, NELLY sees in his silence, that it was.

dialogues.speaker: NELLY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: And did you mean to deliberately humiliate me tonight?

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: You did not like Miss Graves?

dialogues.speaker: NELLY
dialogues.text: You expect me to associate with a woman living so openly with Mr Collins outside of marriage? Entertaining guests as if she were-

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: Nelly-

dialogues.speaker: NELLY
dialogues.text: I do not wish to appear ungrateful. You have been generous, some might say too generous to my family. But I did not realise that I was to be your whore.  61 Blue Revisions dated 11th June 2012 73. DICKENS, floundering-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DICKENS hurries after NELLY, fumbling in her clutchbag.

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: Nelly- NELLY, tear stained and bereft, holds out the bracelet box to DICKENS-

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: It was a mistake- DICKENS reluctantly takes the box. NELLY searches in her bag for her key.

dialogues.speaker: NELLY
dialogues.text: Did you send Catherine to me?

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: NELLY
dialogues.text: How could you be so cruel to her? DICKENS wavers, yet remains silent.

dialogues.speaker: NELLY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: She is the mother of your children.

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: And for that I will always be grateful but I do not love her.

dialogues.speaker: NELLY
dialogues.text: But why-? NELLY’s eyes search with genuine despair.

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: She understands nothing. She sees nothing. I thought if she saw you she would understand that I have nothing with her. I wanted her to see it. DICKENS, consumed by a fury, NELLY shocked, by the volcanic passion.  62 Blue Revisions dated 11th June 2012 74.

dialogues.speaker: NELLY
dialogues.text: It? What is it, Charles? What is it that we are? Would you call us friends? Perhaps we are friends.We listen to one another as if we were. You have been kind..so kind to my family..A friend...And yet you do not feel like a friend. DICKENS stills her hands, cupping her fingers clasping the key.

dialogues.speaker: NELLY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: And when your wife asked me...when she asked me if I was fond of you... I could not honestly reply. I wanted to say ‘No’- A POLICE OFFICER passing, drawn by the noise.

dialogues.speaker: POLICE OFFICER
dialogues.text: Can I be of assistance Sir? DICKENS offers a half smile of reassurance to the POLICE OFFICER.

dialogues.speaker: POLICE OFFICER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Is this young lady troubling you, Sir?

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: No..No..Thank you..She is not troubling me at all. All is well. The POLICE OFFICER nods, moving on- They stand in silence by the door, DICKENS’ hand still resting on NELLY, the key in the lock.

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: May I come in? (silence) Nelly-?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DICKENS and NELLY sit in silence, across the room from one another, NELLY’s quiet fury sobered now. Yet neither able to make a move. A lamp lit low the only light.  63

dialogues.speaker: 63A
dialogues.text: Blue Revisions dated 11th June 2012 75. A vein in DICKENS’ temple pulsing, lost in some deep internal conflict which he cannot speak of, a deep inner consultation of the self until- The PRESS of a floorboard overhead. They both look up, hearts catching in their chests. A cough. MRS TERNAN rolling over in bed. The house once more falls silent.

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: It is late. NELLY nods, makes to stand. DICKENS stands. They look at one another, NELLY makes to show him out. At once he catches her hand, leaning into her, his forehead pressed to hers. NELLY hesitant, sees the despair flickering, in DICKENS face. NELLY’s eyes meet his. They stand, close, lips not yet meeting, breath warm, held in one another’s gaze, lost in silent communion until- DICKENS leans into NELLY, head bowed, his forehead close to her cheek, his body almost buckling. NELLY eases her arms around him, holding him in almost rocking embrace. His fingers intertwine with hers- CLOSE UP ON their hands, intertwined, tentatively exploring, finding one another in these tiny flickering moments of silent physical connection. On NELLY, CLOSE UP, in her face all the conflicting emotions, their lips almost meeting, the barest whisper of a kiss. They stand, entwined and silent-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DICKENS standing with a CARPENTER who is putting shelving and a partition between the dressing room and CATHERINE a DICKENS bedroom. He turns, CATHERINE staring at him, he looks at her with quiet, remorseless gaze.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The crown of a hill, DICKENS just visible head,, NELLY hurrying to keep up, they are lost in conversation. We ar behind them.

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: ...I would walk from the Aldwych to Camden to Highgate then back to Westminster and then on to Millbank.  64 65 66 Blue Revisions dated 11th June 2012 76.

dialogues.speaker: NELLY
dialogues.text: You have London in your blood.

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: Alright? NELLY nods, breathless yet exhilarated.

dialogues.speaker: NELLY
dialogues.text: Yes. Yes-

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: I walk at quite a pace. Their feet walking on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: NELLY walking, boots sinking in the sand- A tiny figure etched across the sand, a dot amidst the vastness of the landscape. INT. CARRIAGE. TRAIN. NEAR STAPLEHURST. KENT. DAY. 1865.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The TEARING STEADY RHYTHM OF TRAIN WHEELS AGAINST STEEL A

dialogues.speaker: TRACK-
dialogues.text: The STREAK of countryside, FLEETING and ABSTRACTED, a BLU light and colour beyond. Then just visible in the glass, NELLY’s reflection indist yet rippling in the glass-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dawn- NELLY and DICKENS just visible walking through the early morning fog, lost in conversation. NELLY strides ahead, turning, holding out a hand pulling him up the hill-

dialogues.speaker: CHARLEY
dialogues.text: Father- CHARLEY DICKENS, books in hand, stops in surprise, eyes falling briefly on NELLY, with quiet recognition.

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: Charley, what are you doing here?  Blue Revisions dated 11th June 2012 77.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLEY
dialogues.text: I walk this way, if I have taken the earlier train-

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: You remember Miss Ternan-? CHARLEY nods to NELLY in greeting, stiffening a little.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLEY
dialogues.text: Of course.

dialogues.speaker: NELLY
dialogues.text: Charley, how are you? You look well.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLEY
dialogues.text: I am.

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: Charley is working in the city.

dialogues.speaker: NELLY
dialogues.text: How very clever.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLEY
dialogues.text: Not really. A friend of father’s.

dialogues.speaker: NELLY
dialogues.text: You are well?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLEY
dialogues.text: Quite well. Thank you Miss Ternan.

dialogues.speaker: NELLY
dialogues.text: I still have the glove. NELLY holds up her gloved hands with a smile.

dialogues.speaker: NELLY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: ..-which you rescued for me. I would have been most unhappy to have lost it. They are my favourite pair.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLEY
dialogues.text: I am sure you would have found another. Perhaps not of equal colour or quality but easy enough to pick up- NELLY stung, DICKENS fury evident in his face. NELLY deflects, saving face-  67 Blue Revisions dated 11th June 2012 78.

dialogues.speaker: NELLY
dialogues.text: We were about to take breakfast. Will you join us?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLEY
dialogues.text: Thank you. I am already late. CHARLEY raises his hat to NELLY, moving swiftly on. Suddenly he stops-—

dialogues.speaker: CHARLEY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Father. (beat) Will we see you at home? DICKENS silent. CHARLEY continues his journey along the path. DICKENS and NELLY together, yet oddly separate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A beautiful summers day- DICKENS family enjoy a garden party, playing mad three legged races on the lawn, orchestrated by DICKENS, who stands caught between reading a newspaper and watching th race.

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: Faster Plorn. Faster. You keep letting everyone else win. The extra leg is there to add to your speed. CATHERINE sits close by drinking tea. GEORGINA seated clo by. DICKENS clutches a newspaper in his hand which he slams d infuriated.

dialogues.speaker: CATHERINE
dialogues.text: You could not keep it quiet forever, Charles. CATHERINE pours herself some tea, looking at DICKENS with distracted concern. CATHERINE (CONT’D) No matter. You must deny it.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGINA
dialogues.text: Rumour can always be denied. We will host Christmas here. Invite everyone we know. Do not worry.  68 Blue Revisions dated 11th June 2012 79.

dialogues.speaker: CATHERINE
dialogues.text: And then you must stop this. DICKENS stiffens.

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: But what if I do not want to?

dialogues.speaker: CATHERINE
dialogues.text: Don’t be foolish. You cannot keep her a secret. Hiding her hurt, CATHERINE withdraws her hand, caught between affection and furious despair. He turns holding h look with direct intent.

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: Yes I can.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The squeak of tin wheels-—

dialogues.speaker: CATHERINE VO
dialogues.text: I can’t read it. Will you read it. Through a door, PLORN pushing a toy train along the floor looks up, watching- CHARLEY takes a copy of a newspaper from CATHERINE who si silent and stiff on a chair. He silently braces himself, reading aloud.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLEY
dialogues.text: There is some domestic trouble of mine, long standing, on which I will make no further remark it being of a sacredly private nature. However-— CATHERINE turns, a look of shocked despair flickering across her face as she sees PLORN peering through the doorway.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLEY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: .-it has lately been brought to an arrangement, which involves no anger or ill-will of any kind. My wife Catherine and I have decided to separate. The headline on the newspaper now clear - CHARLES DICKENS SEPARATES FROM WIFE.  69 70 Blue Revisions dated 11th June 2012 80.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLEY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: The whole origin, progress and surrounding circumstances have been throughout, within the knowledge of my children. The SQUEAK SQUEAK of the tin train just audible as he wheels it away, disappearing along a distant corridor.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLEY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: It is amicably composed, and its details have but to be forgotten by those concerned in it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: NELLY knelt, repotting plants. Looking up to see MARIA, o the approach, pulling off her bonnet and hat en route, holding up a newspaper

dialogues.speaker: CHARLEY VO
dialogues.text: I most solemnly declare that all the lately whispered rumors touching upon my association with a certain young lady are abominably false. Upon my soul and honour there is no-one on earth more virtuous and spotless than this young creature. NELLY wipes down earthy hands, taking the offered paper, reading with shock.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Through a haze of cigar smoke-

dialogues.speaker: CHARLEY VO
dialogues.text: And whosoever says otherwise after this denial, will lie as willfully and as foully as it is possible for any false witness to lie, before Heaven and Earth. A FAT GENTLEMAN sits reading the newspaper, the details o DICKENS separation spilling out- Several other GENTLEMAN sunk in Chesterfields, looking up from the same newspaper, falling into comment-— DICKENS passes, cigar in hand, nodding in stiff greeting- The GENTLEMEN resume their reading- DICKENS moving silently on.  71

dialogues.speaker: 71A
dialogues.text: Blue Revisions dated 11th June 2012 81.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CATHERINE hands sunk in her lap weeping. CHARLEY stands, bitterly hurt and wretched, hovering between consoling CATHERINE and screaming in rage. GEORGINA stands in a doorway, looking on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE on NELLY with MRS TERNAN-

dialogues.speaker: MRS TERNAN
dialogues.text: He has tried to protect you.

dialogues.speaker: NELLY
dialogues.text: But yet I am humiliated.

dialogues.speaker: MRS TERNAN
dialogues.text: There is nothing to deny.

dialogues.speaker: NELLY
dialogues.text: No. The SILENCE hangs-

dialogues.speaker: MRS TERNAN
dialogues.text: What else could he do?

dialogues.speaker: NELLY
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: MRS TERNAN
dialogues.text: He is an honourable man.

dialogues.speaker: NELLY
dialogues.text: He is.

dialogues.speaker: MRS TERNAN
dialogues.text: And you are-

dialogues.speaker: NELLY
dialogues.text: Mama-—

dialogues.speaker: MRS TERNAN
dialogues.text: The most beautiful, wonderful, clever young woman.

dialogues.speaker: NELLY
dialogues.text: But what am I do do with these things. He cannot marry me.

dialogues.speaker: MRS TERNAN
dialogues.text: (beat) No. But what is marriage? (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Blue Revisions dated 11th June 2012 81A.

dialogues.speaker: MRS TERNAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I have been married and it was at times, the loneliest place, Nelly. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 72 73 Blue Revisions dated 11th June 2012 82.

dialogues.speaker: MRS TERNAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Do not think that it will offer you anymore than you already have. They hover on the edge- MRS TERNAN (CONT’D) I have witnessed some of the strongest friendships, some of the most lasting unions between men and women who were never married. I have envied them.

dialogues.speaker: NELLY
dialogues.text: (close to MRS TERNAN) What do I do? MRS TERNAN’s hand gently smoothing back a stray lock of NELLY’s hair.

dialogues.speaker: MRS TERNAN
dialogues.text: Fanny and I leave for Italy at the end of the month. Come with us if you wish. I will book you a passage. It is easily done. NELLY softens, leaning her cheek into MRS TERNAN’s hand, letting her be comforted. MRS TERNAN (CONT’D) This life is precarious. We must take our chances when we can. MRS TERNAN moving on, leaving NELLY alone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: COLLINS, clutching a copy of The Times, hurrying upstairs

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DICKENS bent over a desk, writing-

dialogues.speaker: COLLINS
dialogues.text: Have you gone completely mad? COLLINS, clutching a newspaper, steady on the approach. COLLINS (CONT’D) The Times for God sake. Tell me you have spoken to Catherine first?

dialogues.speaker: SILENCE-
dialogues.text: 74 75 Blue Revisions dated 11th June 2012 83. COLLINS (CONT’D) Christ, Charles. What were you thinking of? COLLINS lost in fury, pacing the room. DICKENS at his des

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: Catherine is the only person I have ever known with whom I can find no common interest. I am impulsive. I claim no immunity from blame. But how, Wilkie? How does one stay married to someone one no longer loves?

dialogues.speaker: COLLINS
dialogues.text: With difficulty. I can see there is no love, but there is a cruelty here.

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: What cruelty? Surely to continue is cruel, Wilkie. To Catherine? An end is an end.

dialogues.speaker: COLLINS
dialogues.text: You've stirred a hive of bees, Charles. You know how this works.You make comment. They print. Then twist. Silence is surely preferable.

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: Is that what they would prefer? Silence..Yes..Then they will have silence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DICKENS walking across the heath, closed within himself. MAN strides past, looks to acknowledge him. DICKENS, keep walking, head down, silent.

dialogues.speaker: INT/EXT. GADS HILL. 1858. NIGHT. 75
dialogues.text: CHARLEY standing at a window, watching with concern, DICK through the window in the backyard, face glowing illumina by a huge bonfire, stoked with letters and bundles of pap which DICKENS hurls with some speed and fury into the towering pyre. He stands, exhausted, yet focused on the task in hand, as reaches for a pile of papers, flicking through them, rejecting them one by one as these too go into the fire, flames illuminating the dark night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 76 Blue Revisions dated 11th June 2012 84.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: NELLY alone, standing by the window the bracelet in her h lost in troubled thought. She absently weaves it through fingers, the rubies glinting INT. DRAWING ROOM. COLLINS HOUSE. LONDON. 1858. EVENING.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: COLLINS sunk in a chair as NELLY paces the room, clearly distraught-

dialogues.speaker: COLLINS
dialogues.text: He can never divorce Catherine, Nelly, you must know that. COLLINS grips her hands, gentle, reassuring. COLLINS (CONT’D) He has burnt all his letters. He has even asked me to burn all our correspondence.

dialogues.speaker: NELLY
dialogues.text: There is an insanity to his behaviour-

dialogues.speaker: COLLINS
dialogues.text: Charles is many things but he is not insane. He is distraught.

dialogues.speaker: NELLY
dialogues.text: And I am not?

dialogues.speaker: COLLINS
dialogues.text: You have a choice. You may distance yourself from him. Find a new life. A different life. NELLY stops, catching on this.

dialogues.speaker: NELLY
dialogues.text: What different life? What is there for me? NELLY looks up just seeing CAROLINE passing a doorway, he eyes briefly grazing over NELLY as she leads BUTLER to be

dialogues.speaker: COLLINS
dialogues.text: He is a good man trying to be a good man. But he is a great man. You see him, Nelly. I watch you together. You see him and he sees you. (close to) What more does one want in life?  77 78 Blue Revisions dated 11th June 2012 85. DISTANT LAUGHTER, CAROLINE and BUTLER lost in some playfu conversation-

dialogues.speaker: CAROLINE
dialogues.text: (calling down) Wilkie- WILKIE with a half smile-

dialogues.speaker: COLLINS
dialogues.text: Coming. (close to) We have to break these conventions. Smash ‘em up. We are the pioneers.

dialogues.speaker: NELLY
dialogues.text: Pioneers? You men - you live your lives while it is we who have to wait. You see a freedom which I don’t see. COLLINS, at a loss-—

dialogues.speaker: COLLINS
dialogues.text: (exiting) The Butler will not sleep if I do not read to her. NELLY nods, alone in the quiet domesticity of COLLINS’ house. She hesitates, three pairs of shoes, COLLINS’, CAROLINE’s and BUTLER’s just visible by the door. The CREAK of FLOORBOARDS-— NELLY looks up- FOOTSTEPS walking over head. SCENE 77 moved now SCENE 71A

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: NELLY passes her coat to JOHN, he takes it closing the do behind him leaving NELLY. She stops on hearing the murmur of DICKENS voice, clearly aloud to himself. She walks finding DICKENS seated at his desk.

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: You are here. NELLY nods, pulling off the last of her things.  79 Blue Revisions dated 11th June 2012 86.

dialogues.speaker: NELLY
dialogues.text: My name is whispered with yours and yet I have nothing. DICKENS takes her by the hands, leading her over towards waiting chair.

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: Sit down. DICKENS hovers, pours her a glass of water.

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Have a glass of water. NELLY quizzical, takes the offered glass, drinks.

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I do not regret it-

dialogues.speaker: NELLY
dialogues.text: Charles-

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: I have broken something that needed breaking. I have finished it.

dialogues.speaker: NELLY
dialogues.text: Yes it is finished.

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: No, the book..the book. NELLY hesitates, DICKENS picks up a sheaf of inky papers, last chapter of Great Expectations, it’s title just visib on the front page. He hands them to her.

dialogues.speaker: NELLY
dialogues.text: Yes, I see. DICKENS nods, takes a seat across from her.

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: (tentatively offering up) Will you read this last part? NELLY wavers, takes it. She opens, reads. She looks up, h watching her. She looks back resumes reading. INT. DRAWING ROOM. TAVISTOCK HOUSE. LONDON. 1858. NIGHT.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Time has passed- NELLY looks up, the pages clutched in her hands. She is moved, yet lost for words, DICKENS watchful, with anxious flickering gaze.  Blue Revisions dated 11th June 2012 87.

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: You do not like it?

dialogues.speaker: NELLY
dialogues.text: No. I like it. I like it very much. DICKENS smiles, relieved, stands, at last able to breath.

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: Wilkie thinks I should change the ending.

dialogues.speaker: NELLY
dialogues.text: No..No. You must not..To bring Estella and Pip together at the end but not to unite them.

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: She is changed. That is enough.

dialogues.speaker: NELLY
dialogues.text: Yes..It is a sad ending but Estella finds her heart, an understanding at last...

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: Exactly.

dialogues.speaker: NELLY
dialogues.text: At times, often Pip is not heroic-

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: Yes..He is filled with the ambitions, the vanities, the flaws in all of us- DICKENS and NELLY’s eyes connect, a sense of total understanding between them, he smiles.

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I know what I have done. But to stay.. To stay as it was. I could not..I cannot..When in my head. .My heart- NELLY moved, DICKENS searching back through the sheaves o manuscript.

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Here..Here..I wrote this..an earlier chapter. (reading You are part of my existence, part of myself.

dialogues.speaker: NELLY
dialogues.text: Yes I remember.  80

dialogues.speaker: 80AA
dialogues.text: Blue Revisions dated 11th June 2012 88. DICKENS nods, spurred on, continuing to read.

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: You have been in every line I have ever read. You have been in every prospect I have ever seen since- on the river, on the sails of the ships, on the marshes, in the clouds, in the light, in the darkness, in the wind, in the woods, in the sea, in the streets. You have been the embodiment of every graceful fancy that my mind has ever become acquainted with- DICKENS stands, raw and open to NELLY-

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: To the last hour of my life, you cannot choose but remain part of my character, part of the little good in me, part of the evil. NELLY moved-

dialogues.speaker: NELLY
dialogues.text: Let us go away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: EXTREME CLOSE UP ON NELLY’s bare feet, navigating over pebbles in a stream. SUDDENLY by her side, DICKENS’ heavy boots- DICKENS HANDS reaching over, guiding her across the strea Beyond a field, on a slight incline, DICKENS leading her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On NELLY, her face flickering with emotions. The shadow o DICKENS, the shape of him, just out of view- SUDDENLY his FINGERS intertwine with hers, their palms fl together, clenched and then released as DICKENS comes- DICKENS, just a shadow, never seen, just a sense of him sinking down next to her, rolling onto his back. NELLY’s relaxes, her head turns a little, lost in the flicking seconds of release after love making.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 81 Blue Revisions dated 11th June 2012 88A.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE on DICKENS, his reflection in a mirror, distracted, face mostly in shadow. One eye caught by the light. Beyon him in the reflection, NELLY in bed, staring at him. A se of the aftermath of love making - not perfect, but someho binding them.

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: (almost to self) You are my magic circle of one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The SCRATCH of DICKEN’s quill, ink blotting his fingers.  82 83 84 Blue Revisions dated 11th June 2012 89. He sits under the shade of trees, writing in a notebook. NELLY sits across from him, revealing she is now heavily pregnant. The remains of a simple picnic on a cloth close a flagon of wine, the last few crumbs of bread and cheese DICKENS looks up from writing, sensing- NELLY watching him, her hands on her dress, now clearly pregnant. SUDDENLY she looks down, the flicker of somethi looks up, smiles, sharing this with him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE UP on ripe apricots, gripped in a cloth in DICKENS HANDS as he walks. He gently tips them on the picnic clot NELLY looks up, with surprise, happy. She reaches for his hands, his fingers blotted with ink. She attempts to wipe ink away, to no avail.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Late afternoon- The stooped frame of an ELDERLY MAN walking towards DICKE and NELLY sunk in the grass-

dialogues.speaker: ELDERLY MAN
dialogues.text: Monsieur Tringham, Madame Tringham, étes-vous préts pour le départ? Aimeriez-vous avoir un peu plus de temps?

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: Non, nous sommes préts. Beyond an ELDERLY WIFE sits in a cart smiling, waiting. T ELDERLY MAN gathers their belongings. DICKENS and NELLY following him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The aftermath of supper, the candle is low, a bottle drained of wine- A MAID quietly clears around them.

dialogues.speaker: NELLY
dialogues.text: (in french) Thank you, Audrey. NELLY stands, close by DICKENS as he sits reading over a letter, she slips an arm around him reading over his shoulder. +e * HF  Blue Revisions dated 11th June 2012 90.

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: I have agreed to fifty more readings.

dialogues.speaker: NELLY
dialogues.text: Where?

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: Glasgow, Manchester, Dublin. I have been asked to give a reading in Paris.

dialogues.speaker: NELLY
dialogues.text: Shall I join you? The SILENCE hangs-

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: There are whisperings-—

dialogues.speaker: NELLY
dialogues.text: Where?

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: In Paris. And if they are in Paris then they will soon be in London. Forster and Wilkie are concerned. I have been out of circulation- On NELLY-

dialogues.speaker: NELLY
dialogues.text: You must go.

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: It is what I am, Nelly.

dialogues.speaker: NELLY
dialogues.text: To the world, yes Charles but to me.. NELLY suddenly concedes, cupping his face, smothering him with kisses-

dialogues.speaker: NELLY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: ...So much more. DICKENS reaches for his pen, in search of paper.

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: No..No..Then I shall not go.

dialogues.speaker: NELLY
dialogues.text: No..No..You shall.

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: No..My mind is quite made up.  85 Blue Revisions dated 11th June 2012 91.

dialogues.speaker: NELLY
dialogues.text: You will. Paris. (with a smile) Paris. How wonderful. NELLY, playful, close to him.

dialogues.speaker: NELLY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (close to) How can you not?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A darkened study the lamps not yet lit- A fire glowing in the hearth, casting its light across th fading darkness of the room. CLOSE ON NELLY as she sits in the half light- The shelves of books, endless copies of Dickens Novels, Oliver Twist, Great Expectations, Edwin Drood and beyond until- A DOORBELL RINGS far off- FOOTSTEPS passing the study door, rising and falling as t dissolve far off- NELLY reaches up, her fingers pulling out a copy of The Frozen Deep- SUDDENLY a door opens, MARY enters-

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Sorry, Ma’am. I didn’t see you there.

dialogues.speaker: NELLY
dialogues.text: It is quite alright Mary. MARY goes to light the lamp.

dialogues.speaker: NELLY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I will do it. MARY hesitates, nods, makes to withdraw-

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Is there anything else, Ma’am. The Guests will be arriving shortly and the glasses are not yet laid.

dialogues.speaker: NELLY
dialogues.text: That is everything.  86 Blue Revisions dated 11th June 2012 92. MARY nods, exits. NELLY looks down at the book in her han She opens it- The open book, a dark curl of baby hair, pressed between pages. NELLY’s finger hesitantly touches it-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE UP ON A bloodied STILLBORN BABY- NELLY lies on a bed, exhausted from the birth. SUDDENLY the MIDWIFE, comes into view, brusquely wrapping STILLBORN CHILD in a cloth and picking it up, to take awa She walks across the room- DICKENS at once, stops her, reaching out a hand. He fumbl in his pocket for a small pen knife, and then- CLOSE UP ON DICKENS’ HANDS, FINGERS GRAZING the STILLBORN CHILD’s head, taking a dark lock between his thumb and forefinger and very gently cutting off a few strands of h The MIDWIFE hesitates, taking the STILLBORN BABY away- DICKENS goes over to NELLY, gently placing the locks in h hand. He closes her fingers around it. The DOCTOR has been standing close by-

dialogues.speaker: DOCTOR
dialogues.text: (in French) I am sorry. Even if they are born perfect in every other way. It happens. The DOCTOR holds out a pen for DICKENS to sign the certificate.

dialogues.speaker: DOCTOR, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (in French) Someone must sign. It is necessary. DICKENS hesitates, looks at NELLY.

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: (in French) He will be buried?

dialogues.speaker: DOCTOR
dialogues.text: (in French) Yes. Of course. Yes.  87 88 89 Blue Revisions dated 11th June 2012 93. EXTREME CLOSE UP on DICKENS HANDS as he signs Monsieur Tringham on the death certificate. INT. PARLOUR/LIBRARY. SCHOOLHOUSE. MARGATE. NIGHT. 1885.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: NELLY closes the book shut, putting it back on the shelf.

dialogues.speaker: AUDIBLE SOUNDS OF PREPARATIONS FROM DEEP WITHIN THE HOUSE
dialogues.text: The sound of last minute music practise, the occasional s of boys, the fleeting snatch of conversation, MARY passin the doorway outside. The sound of a SCHOOLBOY singing jus audible- NELLY stands, the sense of the sea in the late afternoon light through the window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dusk- ON NELLY’s face, etched with absolute desolation. She sta barefooted in the stream.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dawn- DICKENS picking up a manuscript of Our Mutual Friend, fro a table as he moves on. NELLY stands in her coat and hat, the light from the open doorways, slowly dimming to darkness as shutters are clos by a MAID. DICKENS packs the last of his things, close by

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: Have you left the keys on the table? NELLY absently nods.

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Only I promised Monsieur Duboit..There is a very nice family from Rouen who wish to winter here. DICKENS passes her.

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Nelly? The distant shutters, closing, sinking them into darkness  90 91 Blue Revisions dated 11th June 2012 94.

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Say something. (silence)

dialogues.speaker: SAY SOMETHING
dialogues.text: NELLY silent until- She caves, her body suddenly overwhelmed with grief, DICK looking on, unable to help her, wanting to but stricken b the overwhelming pain and grief that he sees. Her sobs audible, fighting her way out of this agony. Her tears at last subsiding, she slowly gathers herself.

dialogues.speaker: NELLY
dialogues.text: We shall miss our train.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The swirl of steam and swell of COMMUTERS hurrying along platform past a STATION GUARD-

dialogues.speaker: STATION GUARD
dialogues.text: (calling out) All passengers arrived from France this train for London. DICKENS reaching out to help NELLY onto the train, gloved hands briefly touch, NELLY nearly misses her footing. NEL quietly reassuring, DICKENS following her on the train- A TICKET COLLECTOR punches their tickets-

dialogues.speaker: TICKET COLLECTOR
dialogues.text: My wife says she should marry Rokesmith and be done. DICKENS smiles, clutching a sheaf of papers, blotted with familiar scrawl, title Our Mutual Friend just visible.

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: Perhaps the next chapter. The squawk of gulls overhead. INT. CARRIAGE. TRAIN. NEAR STAPLEHURST. KENT. DAY. 1865.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The TEARING STEADY RHYTHM OF TRAIN WHEELS AGAINST STEEL A

dialogues.speaker: TRACK-
dialogues.text: The STREAK of countryside, FLEETING and ABSTRACTED, a BLU light and colour beyond. Then just visible in the glass, NELLY’s reflection indist yet rippling in the glass-  92 93 94 Blue Revisions dated 11th June 2012 95. PULL OUT TO REVEAL NELLY, quietly absent, face pale, star out of the train and seated opposite her-

dialogues.speaker: PULL OUT TO AT LAST TO REVEAL THE SHADOWY FIGURE CAUGHT T
dialogues.text: GLASS AS DICKENS lost in correcting papers, blotted with familiar scrawl, the title Our Mutual Friend just visible A distant GUFFAW, from the neighbouring compartment. DICKENS looks over at NELLY-

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: Sleep and when you wake we shall be home. NELLY catches on this, she looks at him. Then closes her eyes, trying to sleep, grief ever present, the ruby bracelet on her wrist.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The train, pistons pumping, whistling along the track- INT. CARRIAGE. TRAIN. NEAR STAPLEHURST. KENT. DAY. 1865.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The TEARING STEADY RHYTHM OF TRAIN WHEELS AGAINST STEEL A

dialogues.speaker: TRACK-
dialogues.text: The SCRATCH SCRATCH of his pen, against paper. CLOSE UP ON NELLY looking out of the window, trying to sl eyes catching on the fleeting landscape. DICKENS lost in total concentration- Suddenly, the train violently jolts- The scream of PASSENGERS and screech of metal as carriage visibly buckle- The smash of glass, hands reaching out, NELLY, at once, WHIPPED out of her seat arms thrown forward in useless protection, FLUNG through a split carriage, and HURLED through splinters of glass, a world upturned-

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS OOV
dialogues.text: (shouting out) Nelly-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: NELLY, eyes flickering open, her body twisted, her arm at odd angle, perhaps broken- Around, the scatter of luggage, a trunk split open; silk undergarments caught on a rowan bush.  Blue Revisions dated 11th June 2012 96. NELLY’s POV of the buckled wreckage of the train. DICKENS clambering out of a severed carriage, scrabbling down the grassy bank, towards her. Around him the TWIST OF WRECKAGE, BODIES LITTERED, the

dialogues.speaker: PORTER
dialogues.text: Sir- Beyond the screams and shouts of the injured, a PORTER dazed, but in charge, moving amongst them.

dialogues.speaker: PORTER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: We are asking everyone able bodied if they could help with the most injured.

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: Yes of course. I must help. Water. People will need water.

dialogues.speaker: PORTER
dialogues.text: (beat) Is it Mr Dickens, Sir? DICKENS hesitates, nods looking to NELLY, concerned not wanting to leave her-

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: PORTER
dialogues.text: Were you travelling alone, Sir? NELLY’s eyes catching on DICKENS, willing him to turn awa

dialogues.speaker: NELLY
dialogues.text: (hushed/exhaled) Go..go. NELLY’s heart beat, thumping in her head until-

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS OOV
dialogues.text: Yes..Yes. Quite alone. This young lady is in need of assistance. DICKENS turns, with a look of absolute despair as he walk away, as he turns his head away from view.

dialogues.speaker: PORTER
dialogues.text: We are dealing with the most injured first. NELLY’s vision fades, the blurry figure of DICKENS walkin away.  95 Blue Revisions dated 11th June 2012 97.

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS OOV
dialogues.text: I’‘1l do what I can... NELLY’s hands clasp the PORTER, not wanting to let him go slipping in and out of consciousness.

dialogues.speaker: PORTER
dialogues.text: Madam, I will get one of the ladies to attend to you as soon as. The PORTER nods to two YOUNG LADIES on the approach.

dialogues.speaker: PORTER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (moving off) This way, Sir. The two YOUNG LADIES pass, coming quickly to NELLY’s aid with DICKENS seen following the PORTER.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG LADIES
dialogues.text: You poor dear. Beyond the young TICKET COLLECTOR, wide eyed and dead, thrown across the twisted track. NELLY, with the two YOUN LADIES, comforting her. YOUNG LADIES (CONT’D) We are here...We are here. DICKENS moving amongst the dead, the dying and the wounde offering brandy. A page of Our Mutual Friend caught in the grass of the embankment. DICKENS flattens it out, splattered with ink and blood, pocketing it before moving on-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A thin pamphlet/ programme No Thoroughfare: A Drama in Fi Acts by Mr Wilkie Collins placed down on a chair by a SCHOOLBOY methodically moving a long a row of seats. The of chairs being laid out by two SCHOOLBOYS beyond- The back of the hall, a MAID hurries to finish last minut decorations, polish glasses and light lamps and candles o table laid out with a magnificent buffet- The first PARENTS arriving led by MARY, GEORGE coming for to greet them, offering brief exchange, gesturing towards table. CLOSE ON GEORGE turning to LAMBOURNE-

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: (hushed) Where is my wife?  96 97 Blue Revisions dated 11th June 2012 98.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: NELLY walking fast. A small church ahead of her. We might sense the sea. Spiky winter trees, her breathing as she walks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: NELLY enters a small graveyard. She is a lone figure standing amongst the gravestones.

dialogues.speaker: BENHAM, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Ellen Ternan. NELLY turns, surprised. BENHAM standing near the entrance the church, caught in the half light. His face slightly shadowed by a hat.

dialogues.speaker: NELLY
dialogues.text: (nods ) Yes. That was my name. You have always known this?

dialogues.speaker: BENHAM
dialogues.text: Suspected. Things you said, comments, memories of Mr Dickens that were not a child’s memories. NELLY stands, distracted, BENHAM sensing she needs someth from him. BENHAM gestures to a bench to one side of the s cemetery.

dialogues.speaker: BENHAM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I saw him read once. It was magical. Row upon row craning forward, marvelling at this transformation. One forgets that he was more than writer, more than actor. He would pull you soaring, spinning into the heart of another world. BENHAM smiles, betraying his utter admiration.

dialogues.speaker: BENHAM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I have lived my life in the pages of those novels. BENHAM smiles, suddenly moved.

dialogues.speaker: BENHAM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I should not have expected their author to live so quiet a life. BENHAM quietly considers NELLY.  Blue Revisions dated 11th June 2012 99.

dialogues.speaker: BENHAM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You inspired him.

dialogues.speaker: NELLY
dialogues.text: Perhaps. I don’t know. I would say Maybe we inspired each other. It was not easy our friendship. Never quite knowing when one would see him, when or even if he would arrive. It was often fragile -And yet there were days of such joy..such celebration. .When we would talk..laugh together. .But there were moments towards the end when I dreaded his visits...perhaps even his touch. But we needed each other. In our secret life. I was his magic circle of one. (beat) There was a day, when he took me to the house, where I was to live. She gets lost in her thought.

dialogues.speaker: BENHAM
dialogues.text: Mrs Wharton Robinson- NELLY, trying to make sense of it, searching for words.

dialogues.speaker: NELLY
dialogues.text: I have thought about it often. The moment when I finally accepted what our life was to be. (beat) He knew he would leave me first. That he would die first. NELLY lost deep within herself.

dialogues.speaker: NELLY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Charles understood that however painful it is, we are alone. Whoever we are with, we are alone. And he was right. Great Expectations. He wrote an ending - It was his first instinctive ending. A good ending, the best ending- Pip and Estella do not come together. Pip sees that she will never be his. Later they wanted him to change it. Some people thought it too brutal. So instead Pip finals words are - “I saw the shadow of no parting from her” - He ends the book in shadows, you see, a place of uncertainty, of haunting. And that is where I have been living. Do you see-?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 98 Blue Revisions dated 11th June 2012 100. BENHAM stares at her.

dialogues.speaker: BENHAM
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: NELLY
dialogues.text: And I will not live there anymore. They sit; it is almost dark. EXT. ELIZABETH COTTAGE. WINDSOR. 1865. DAY.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The front of a pretty cottage, DICKENS walks towards door, turns to NELLY guiding her in. INT. BEDROOM. ELIZABETH COTTAGE. WINDSOR. 1865. DAY.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The PRESS of a FOOT on a floorboard- NELLY’s stands, arm heavily bandaged peering into a bedroom. She enters, eyes tracing over the simple yet comfortably furnished sitting room. DICKENS hovers in the doorway, clutching his hat.

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: The house is to your liking?

dialogues.speaker: NELLY
dialogues.text: Yes. I am happy to see the castle from the window.

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: And there is a fire in every room. I have taken the liberty of employing a nurse who will attend to you. A local woman but of good kind. NELLY hesitates, nods-

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: It is a sleepy market town, but there is a very fine butchers. And the church is newly restored. You must visit.

dialogues.speaker: NELLY
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: 97A
dialogues.text: a front 98  Blue Revisions dated 11th June 2012 101.

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: The fast train from Paddington takes 18 minutes. Or alternatively there is a train to Windsor from Victoria or Waterloo which also serves well.

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Nelly-? NELLY stares out at the castle, floating far off across t fields, suspended above the mist.

dialogues.speaker: NELLY
dialogues.text: It is as if it is floating. NELLY forces a smile, quietly broken.

dialogues.speaker: NELLY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You will come to see me?

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: NELLY
dialogues.text: Weekly?

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: Of course. Twice if I can.

dialogues.speaker: NELLY
dialogues.text: I see. And if I need anything-?

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: You need only ask.

dialogues.speaker: NELLY
dialogues.text: And am I to expect you at weekends and holidays?

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: Nelly-

dialogues.speaker: NELLY
dialogues.text: Of course I am sure when you can.

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: Please-

dialogues.speaker: NELLY
dialogues.text: And shall we keep Tringham?

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: (beat) Yes.  99 Blue Revisions dated 11th June 2012 102.

dialogues.speaker: NELLY
dialogues.text: Then this is how it is to be now, Charles. DICKENS caught in its unbearable hold.

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: Whatever I have tried to do in life, I have tried with all my heart to do it well. Whatever I have devoted myself to I- DICKENS unable to find words-

dialogues.speaker: NELLY
dialogues.text: Don’t, Charles. Don’t explain. DICKENS looks at her, suddenly exhausted, all his inner defences crumbling.

dialogues.speaker: NELLY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: There is nothing to say. NELLY looks at him calmly. DICKENS stares back at her.

dialogues.speaker: NELLY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Everyone has their secret. And this is ours.

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: Yes. NELLY reaches over to him awkwardly, her arm giving her discomfort. She kisses him gently on the forehead - almos if he were a boy.

dialogues.speaker: NELLY
dialogues.text: So much more complicated than anything one could write ina book. Yet he seems aged and frail, vulnerable, depleted, leanin into NELLY.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: NELLY pulls off her coat and hat- Beyond, the MURMUR of VOICES, MUSICIANS TUNING UP- MARY on the approach, carrying a tray of drained punch glasses-—  100 Blue Revisions dated 11th June 2012 103.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Where have you been? Mr Wharton Robinson has been looking for you everywhere. NELLY nods, face flushed from the cold.

dialogues.speaker: NELLY
dialogues.text: Mary, will you tell my husband I wish to see him. MARY, clearly anxious, nods, moving on.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: The doorbell’s not stopped and they’re half way through the punch. Through an ajar door, PARENTS seated, the RUSTLE and RIPP of excitement, the play about to begin- INT. PARLOUR/LIBRARY. SCHOOLHOUSE. MARGATE. NIGHT. 1885.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The clock chimes seven- A SENSE OF GROWING NOISE, THE SOUND OF PEOPLE’s CHATTER,

dialogues.speaker: WORLD OF PARENTS JUST AUDIBLE PASSING OUTSIDE THE DOOR-
dialogues.text: NELLY waiting-

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE OOV
dialogues.text: Nelly- The DOOR SWINGS OPEN, GEORGE enters-

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: You are late. It is nearly dark. Where have you been? NELLY springs up, going over to GEORGE, reaching out for

dialogues.speaker: NELLY
dialogues.text: George. I am so sorry. I am here. I am here. She grips him tighter. GEORGE softening, holding her, wit genuine concern, his eyes searching hers-

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Are you quite well? NELLY, on the edge of speaking-

dialogues.speaker: NELLY
dialogues.text: Yes, George. Quite well. GEORGE looks at NELLY, his hands cupping her face, her ha windswept, cheeks flushed.  Blue Revisions dated 11th June 2012 104.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Are you sure?

dialogues.speaker: NELLY
dialogues.text: I walked with Mr Benham today. We talked about Mr Dickens-

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Yes-—

dialogues.speaker: NELLY
dialogues.text: George- NELLY wavers, suddenly unable to continue-

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: The memories of a child, Nelly. GEORGE holds NELLY’s eyes with complicit understanding.

dialogues.speaker: NELLY
dialogues.text: Yes-—

dialogues.speaker: ROAR
dialogues.text: SUDDENLY GEOFFREY enters, a mop of golden curls, his face painted like a lion, with rope mane, rushes roaring into the drawing room, straight into NELLY’s arms.

dialogues.speaker: NELLY
dialogues.text: Darling, you will frighten our guests—

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: I think he is trying to frighten his mother. NELLY laughs, the moment broken, hurriedly buries her tea stained face into his neck, kissing his cheeks, then GEOR They stand in the half light of early evening, entwined i silent embrace until-

dialogues.speaker: NELLY
dialogues.text: Geoffrey. Go. You must take your place. GEOFFREY runs off, leaving NELLY and GEORGE.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Are you ready? NELLY nods, laughs, at the sheer exhaustion of it all, gripping his arm-  101 102 Blue Revisions dated 11th June 2012 105.

dialogues.speaker: NELLY
dialogues.text: Yes, George. I am ready. GEORGE opens the door and walks into the light of the hallway. We are with NELLY as she goes through the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The FACES OF THE PARENTS silent and watching- CLOSE TO NELLY, behind her head. The sense of the SCHOOLB on stage, the sequence we saw at the beginning, alive on stage-

dialogues.speaker: SCHOOL BOY 1
dialogues.text: Well, my lads, the day has broken at last. CLOSE IN ON NELLY watching the play unfold, the camera moving around her- SCHOOL BOY 1 (CONT’D) What do you say to the weather, now?

dialogues.speaker: SCHOOL BOY 2
dialogues.text: I say the weather will do.

dialogues.speaker: SCHOOL BOY 3
dialogues.text: I say doubtful!

dialogues.speaker: SCHOOL BOY 2
dialogues.text: I say - bad! A sense of GEORGE by NELLY’s sides. CLOSE ON NELLY. NELLY’s POV- DICKENS, as seen in Manchester, in the last throes of dying on the stage of the Free Trade Hall-

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: Come nearer! My mind clears, but my eyes grow dim. Kiss me, kiss me before I die. CLOSE ON DICKENS as he dies, his eyes glaze over, falling limp in the arms of MARIA, not seen, his dead eyes glazin over as if looking straight at NELLY- CLOSE ON NELLY tears glistening, a life shared together h in that look-

dialogues.speaker: AT ONCE RAPTUROUS APPLAUSE-
dialogues.text: Blue Revisions dated 11th June 2012 106. A row of SCHOOLBOYS, GEOFFREY at its heart bowing before delighted audience.

dialogues.speaker: ALL
dialogues.text: Bravo..Bravo. NELLY flushed and happy, eyes stung with tears of pride, clapping. She looks over to BENHAM, he smiles at her, wit shared understanding.

dialogues.speaker: BENHAM
dialogues.text: (mouthed) Bravo. NELLY turns to GEORGE, gripping his hand. GEORGE squeezes yet clearly something irrevocably changed. They turn back smiling at GEOFFREY a mop of golden curls.
